number of helpful: 18 of 29 people (62%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 25, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a Magic:The Gathering player, I really like this new concept on CCGs.Pros:Free to play!!Variety of possible deck builds whether you are playing casually with friends or playing constructed.Dailies are easy to complete to help boost card collection without the need to spend money.You get to keep all the cards you choose for draft (except on Legendary draft), unlike Hearthstone.I really enjoy having the play the best current hand since all cards are reshuffled/discarded after the turn.  Makes combos a little more difficult to land but worth it when they do.Card of the Day and Alternate Art are nice if you want to spend money.Cons:Drafts can get frustrating when most players choose the same type of draft deck.Some cards/decks are definitely balanced a bit more favorably.  (Varna's Pact giving the possibility of playing all four factions can be annoying if luck works in favor)Leveling cards (although I like it) can be a bit too random when hitting higher ranks but still pulling low level cards.Cards of the Day and Alternate art makes me want to spend money...People you play during tournaments and random online matches get added to Friends List (wish there was a separation)All in all: I rate this game at about an 8.5/10.  It is still a new game but I spend a good amount of time playing with friends each day, even if it is a single game that might take 16 hours due to work schedules and time zones.  I really enjoy trying to mix cards and make new combos for specific type of decks (Mobility, Swarm, Health Gain, Poison, Tarsus)

number of helpful: 9 of 12 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 31
Name: SolForgeDeveloper: Stone Blade EntertainmentDate: 2016Genre: CCGOrientation: MultiplayerPopulation: DeadPerspective: 2D - Top-Down - StaticTimeflow: Asynchronous Turn-Based, Match-Based, Pass-And-Play, Turn-BasedSkills: BrainSetting: ConfluxUniverse: SolisStyle: -Tags: 1v1, Competitive, Cross-Platform, DailiesModel: F2PContent: Big DLC, Collectible, MicrotransactionsPlatforms: PC, Mac, Android, iOSReview: F2P CCG with somewhat unique rules, utilizing 5 board lanes, forced combat, evolving cards, player level-ups, turn-replacing hands, indefinite deck reshuffling; along with couple interesting card mechanics. Conflux setting here is a mix of faeries, robots, mages, tanks, zombies, drones, dinosaurs, nano technologies, elementals, protomans, mechs, demigods etc., all divided into 4 factions by interests, without neutrals.	Deckbuilding: 30 decksize / 3 copies / 1-2 factions; no other limits and no resourses.	Draft system, constructed tournaments, "Weekend Warrior" tournaments with new rules every week. Competitive ladder and casual mode. Timed and untimed turn queues. Pass-and-play mode, to play with ur friend on 1 device. And even "asynchronous turn-based" mode, reminiscent of ancient play-by-email games, when both players do their turns independently (though, sequentially) whenever they come online. And.. "Play Random Deck" button, dammit seriously, how often do you see it in card games, think about it?? :D	Half of the features above were unreasonably cut on later stages. Or reasonably; does it matter though?.. (find me reason to cut "Play Random Deck" function btw)	SolForge spent in beta ridiculously huge period of time - playable state was around 2012 afaik, so 4 years after kickstarter finished, at least. (If this isn't obvious hint, than what?..)	Card art is wonderful and 300% deserves permanent place on my harddrive. Looks very professional, especially among hoards of these Hearthstone-wannabes. To remind, conflux arts require separate talents, at the very least 1 for each setting. All creatures here are drawn in 3 evolution levels (or 4, if OP :D), like your pokemons, normal->Cooler->SUPERCOOL. Girls are hot, undead are sadistic, mechs are heavy, giants are brutal, etc.	It will be remembered by me personally as a card game with most generous business model ever seen. For long time they were giving 2 boosters + currency + tickets EVERY day - just for playing couple games vs AI. After huge game rework, daily boosters were reduced to 1 (with small chance of getting 10) and AI games were no longer counted, but still. I heard veterans talking about tournament rewards being overgenerous as well. The fact should speak for itself: without giving a penny or actually playing ANYTHING except dailies, ever - my collection as of today contains: playsets of everything except last 2 rarities | 5/7 expansions with playsets of penultimate rarity | at least 1 of each ultimate rarity, 2/3 of them are playsets or 2 of. In the game with 7 sets and ~770 cards of 4 rarities total. I don't have a single alt art card for bragging though, for reason above (most aa don't even look cool though -.-). -------<[CUT]>-------	Another reason for remembering - the record amount of boosters I opened at once - 1111. Not in one sit, accumulated amount was opened in 3 days with pauses. Could be little more, but yeah, for the cool number. And anyway I don't think I will ever reach that number in any other game, physical or digital. Total amount of SolForge boosters was ~1500, plus couple "Legendary Chests" - big boosters with guaranteed ultimate + penultimate rarities inside.	And the last reason, I will remember it as a game I used to continuously collect, and never got to actually play it, even once. Except for campaign and AI skirmishes =D	SolForge is OPD as of today, January 31, 2017.Class: III - Dead BreadVerdict: YesReviewed: 1.31.2017Approach: Steam - PCTime: Several Dozen HoursDeeds:  1111 Boosters Opened At Once Collection: Playsets of everything except last 2 rarities | 5/7 expansions with playsets of penultimate rarity | at least 1 of each ultimate rarity, 2/3 of them are playsets or 2 of

content:
Posted: January 29, 2015
Early Access Review
								So apparently this game was made early last year?  Graphics aren't everything for sure, but this game looks like it could've been made a few years ago as one of those completely free flash games.  While playing Solforge I've been trying to look past it, but unfortunately this game has too many parts that seem to have been totally overlooked.My biggest complaints:No tutorial that goes beyond "drag and drop to play your cards, press these obvious buttons to end your turn, here's a quick explanation for the leveling and rank system, here's how spells and effects sorta-work, good luck!".  The game doesn't really explain the various factions in any form or the way that thier ally abilities work, now does it go on to explain any sort of basic strategy in this game at all.  There's so much missing for a game that's already a year old.The card balance is pretty bad.  There are several cards that are simply better than other ones.  There are several clones of Zombie Soldier that have the same stats as well as an added effect, for instance.There's no undo button, which is pretty vital for a card game.  You can't undo any actions whatsoever.  This is especially annoying when you start to realize the full potential of the battle and turn phases being seperated.The interface as a whole isn't as streamlined as it could be.  It works better than most games that have recently come out, with thier 20 buttons and 50 menus at least, but it's much nicer to click on a button that says "settings" over fishing around for a cog symbol....There's only 4 factions, and no lore.  I don't understand why factions even exist except to have those little ally effects, but almost all of the ally effects pool into Tempys so they don't matter very much.There are too many similar cards, except for spell cards.  The spell cards tie into my aforementioned gripes about the card balance in this game, where one faction has many powerful spell cards while another faction has some OK ones to get by on.  I could understand it if 1 of the factions had particularly strong spells and particularly weak creatures, but this isn't the case.  Because half of the monsters in this game could be clones with very minor stat differences.In summary, I'm glad that I got these starter packs in a huge Humble Bundle, because I would have regret my starter pack puchase if I had not.  I'm going back to Infinity Wars, I'll take its' more punishing economy over this game's less fun, less explodey, less varietal gameplay.

content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								Waited a while for them to fix the glaring problems with this game, to no avail:-The bias towards higher rarity cards to the point of almost disregarding lower rarity ones (and screwing up the new player experience in the process, together with the recent reduction of daily rewards)-The excessive accelerated pace of the meta game (spam or die), which wouldn't be such an awful thing if: there was any kind of match making involved on unraked games, and most of the cards needed to counter said meta weren't placed in the upper rarities  (there is something off when you are worrying about countering the meta in casual mode).-The lack of options regarding buying booster packs of a desired expansion (having only the options of buying the most recent one with cash or an all-in-one pack that dilutes the chances of getting the card your are aiming for quite badly)Honestly, the lag in the new client and some other technical issues, at least in my eyes, can be waited out and fixed. But the other issues really turn me away from the game. It is truly an interesting concept for a CCG, with interesting mechanics, but with the glacial pace of the development, the issues that remain unsolved, and a whole world of other CCGs out there, the game ain't worth much of your time just yet. However I would say that you should keep an eye on this one, here's hoping they manage to turn this around.

												I honestly used to love this game. Just take a look at my Steam screenshots, I think there's only one in there that ISN'T of a SolForge game. But, as with many other users and reviewers, they lost me when the new expansion came out.  I had saved up "free" (you get them from winning games) packs for months, along with tons of silver, which is the ingame currency that costs no real money, only real time. The plan was to get as many of these exciting new cards as possible as soon as the expansion came out, which I did. I opened all 100 packs (a significant and rather dull time investment) and spend hundreds of thousands of silver on new cards from the "Raiders Unchained" set. Two weeks later, every single one of those cards was gone, and 0 silver or packs were refunded to my account. It's possible that every card from the packs I opened that day was removed; I don't know the list of what I did or didn't have beforehand well enough to check. But I know that I'm done with this game, and I can't recommend that anyone else play it.

Early Access Review
								The visual overhaul removed a lot of the functional and attractive graphics and smart decisions of the previous interface, and each new set FURTHER nerfs the older sets more than the last release. Do yourself a favor and skip this game. You don't need to nerf old card to make new cards. If you can't avoid power creep that's fine, some cards will just be less good in time, as is the case for all CCG, but there's a cardinal flaw in your design process if you think nerfing player tools is the right answer; make the things that are too weak by comparison a little stronger to make up for it. Thanks for trying Solforge team, your game was fun for a while.

content:
Posted: June 28, 2016
Early Access Review
								If you ever think about starting playing, here is my take: just don't. Turn around now, while you can.Let me start with the positive stuff: The underlying system, the variance of cards and as such the potential for deckbuilding is great. The game itself works well. Artwork is nice, tournaments are sometimes fun.And now for the bad: it is not at all friendly to new players. Play online and you WILL run into highend decks. Nothing else can compete at this stage. There is no learning curve. You either have the good cards, or you get stomped by one of the 5 dominant decks of the meta at the time. Sure, you can get cards for free, but, sadly, now you need to win an ONLINE game for that. Same for tournament tickets. This was different, before the client redesign. Nowadays, there is no way for you to get your toes wet, so to speek. It's a bad system and it is not getting better.Right now, if you are ready to drop a lot of money on a card game, you could do worse than SolForge. But if not? Stay the hell away.

content:
Posted: February 10, 2015
Early Access Review
								Having just uninstalled the game after 70 hours of playtime the reason can be summed up to a single word "greed". Now as a gamer one has to think what is the value I am getting for my money. When I compare the value I have gotten for my money from current master of digital CCG's Hearthstone one has to conclude that Solforge is a ripoff in comparison.There are a few reasons for this lack of value:A) The rewards for tournaments are weak for example one has to win all matches to get enough game's F2P currency of silver to play another. B)The rewards for playing the game are at most an insult i.e. you will get 100 silver per win and less than 10k for dailies and you need 60k(casual) or 140k(competative) to enter a draft so you do the math.C)So as the prices of everything are beyond reach of F2P currency one has to spend a lot of money in order to actually play the game and then feel bad as you will probably lose at the tournament and get nothing for you money.Now obviously as I spent over 70 hours on the game I actually liked the game mechanics, but come to realize that I like roller coaster rides as well but doing them daily is just not economically viable. So back to Hearthstone wherein I am happy to spend some money as I don't feel rippedoff at the end of it all.

content:
Posted: February 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Interesting take on the CCG where you don't have resources to play, just limited number of plays per turn.  I wanted to like it, especially since it has an Android port which meant I could play it on the go.  Something Hearthstone has just recently added.  The single player vs AI is smooth and decent for trying out new decks and getting daily rewards.  However, the problem, and why I have to say not recommended, comes from the abyssmal responsiveness and overall laggy feeling of any actual multi-player game.  I have a feeling since it has an Android port, even on the PC it doesn't stay connected to game servers and only periodically communicates.  In multiplayer games that seems to be when you finish your turn or your opponent finishes theirs.  Occasionally I've seen part of an opponent turn, then wait 30 seconds, then the 2nd part of their turn.  I guess they needed to think.  It feels very rough and unfinished and doesn't stand up to Hearthstone or MTG.  I wanted to like it.  But I don't.

content:
Posted: November 25, 2013
Early Access Review
								Wow, so Brian Kibler (Magic The Gathering Pro) designed his own card game, I'll bet it's ROCK solid eh?Nope.This game is literally 99% luck, there's no trading between players, rarer cards absolutely decimate cards that are less rare (eventually you'll get an all-rare deck) and you will lose games because they drew Level 3 cards and you drew Level 1 cards.Now let me explain, the fundamental mechanic here is when a card is played it goes back into your deck, but it levels up. As a card levels up it gets better. You can play two cards per turn and discard the remainder (so they go into your deck but don't level up) while drawing 5 cards at the start of your turn.What does this mean?You can't hold cards until they're strategically useful, you just have to play what you got.Mid game is dominated by level 2 and level 3 cards as neither player will have access to them.Late game is entirely dominated by level 3 cards and the loser is often whoever has less rare cards available to them.The limit of cards played per turn makes cards that grow in power amazingly good, or cards that can deal with multiple cards.This means that with the correct combination of spells it's easy to quickly create a giant creature that's unkillable and will win you the game.Of course with the correct combination of spells it's easy to dismantle that strategy but c'est la vie.So is this game fun? Definitely, the mechanics are fun.Is this game worth money? Definitely not. While the mechanics are fun and interesting they don't really reward skillful play, many games will be lost to simply drawing level 1 and level 2 cards when the opponent plays two level 3 cards and then two more the following turn.Worth a bit of fun if you don't care about winning/losing for no apparent reason.

number of helpful: 30 of 54 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								Uninstalled SolForge today, which at some level is a shame because without the P2W aspects it was a fun, albeit low strategy CG, but it does highlight the difference between how gamers and F2P devs define what is a “good” game.Unfortunately games that follow the Asian F2P whale model task the developers to build a “good” game from a gamer’s POV while simultaneously breaking balance in a way that can only be ameliorated with a credit card.From this gamer’s perspective a “good” CG offers a level playing field emphasizing skill by increasing strategy (in deck construction to maximize card synergy and in variety of play style choices during a match), decreasing luck of the draw aspects (leaving just enough fate to keep it interesting, but not so much to make it feel random), and striving to have balance between card choices. In contrast from an Asian model F2P dev’s perspective a “good” CG game is one that drives whales to obsessively use the cash shop to increase their chances of getting overpowered cards relative to those commonly available through in game currency transactions; it is a basic intermittent positive reinforcement operant conditioning design to foster compulsive spending. In this model cash flow can be maximized by downplaying strategy to favor accessibility (also a problem in B2P these days), luck of the draw is increased so one can never feel quite secure enough with their decks, as well as allowing less skilled players to stand a better chance of also winning, and by purposely breaking balance so one is constantly striving to fill their decks with more OP cards than their competitors.Specifically the SolForge monetization pit is built around the absurdly imbalanced legendary cards and the increasing of rank of cards.While the gambling aspects of trying to acquire OP legendary cards in bulk booster pack purchases is obviously a cash grab, the leveling of cards is a more subtle monetization tactic. At first I thought leveling was a cool idea as I always like playing games where I can nurture my units with experience to greater power, but here it is used to further exaggerate card imbalance. While on average a legendary level I card is somewhat more beneficial than non-legendary one, it usually isn’t in a game breaking way; it is at end game when level III is achieved that the P2W aspect manifests in full, and games come to an abrupt end, virtually always at the expense of the non-whale without red star cards.So one can break open their wallets and start enriching their decks with reds (but don’t be surprised if you just end up losing in turn to a larger whale) or try to enjoy the game with the exclusion of legendaries, smartly avoiding the overt monetization mechanics by immediately dropping from matches when a legendary comes into play; if one is a small fish in a sea of whales you are going to have to accept that you'll be taking the whale bone frequently, and don't expect the devs to step in because they designed the F2P game to foster just that feeling of unjust frustration on the loser's part, and the thrill of crushing victory on the whale's side. So since the whales are paying to keep the game afloat, the freebie players need to respect that and give them their due, but one should feel absolutely no responsibility to get ridden for longer than necessary. Just immediately concede and get on with a balanced match in spite of the SolForge dev's intentions. By analogy I wouldn’t find it entertaining to join in a seven card stud tournament, where I am restricted to five cards; could I win, perhaps, but obviously the cards would be stacked against me, so why bother?I do like seeing the non-heroic/non-legendary player sponsored tournaments in the forums, but of course even their existence points to the ugly pink whale in the middle of the room.This last day of playing, even among decks of comparable strength, I found the sheer luck factor was too much for me to ignore. We have all been there where in late game the opponent is playing out III’s and II’s and by the chance of the draw we get a hand of I’s which stinks to lose in such a way. Conversely I can’t help but to feel sympathetic when I just played out a couple of III’s and the opposing player blocks with two level I’s; you kind of want to send them a “sorry” emote. Lastly I think such power disparity fosters a virulent community of frustrated players that in my experience won’t think twice about walking away from a match to slowly let the timer run down once the realize they lost, as if to say ♥♥♥♥ you.Give me a B2P CG where everyone has access to all of the cards, and I’ll pull out my credit card happily, but there is no way I am going to constantly ride the red legendary dragon FTW! ;) http://www.gamasutra.com/view/feature/195806/chasing_the_whale_examining_the_.php?print=1

number of helpful: 4 of 4 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 13, 2016
Early Access Review
								This used to be a viable, low-cost alternative to titles such as Magic: The Gathering and Hearthstone, which I used to enjoy playing on mobile and occasionally on the computer. It used to have a client which was graphically unimpressive, reminiscent of Hearthstone with almost no graphics other than a background image and card images, but functional. The game used to be very generous, giving you tickets to play in tournaments/draft vs real players and letting you build your collection when playing vs AI. The highlight for me, not having a large collection, was "draft" mode, where you built your deck from a selection of cards, then faced opponents who did the same.As of June, however, the client and the game have changed dramatically. Client is now full of effects that remind you of the '80s and are unskippable, slowing down gameplay, health ticks down slowly and takes seconds to display accurately. Game is buggy and will seemingly randomly delete your decks. In the three ranked games at the lowest rank I played yesterday, the 1st match was bugged and required me to leave the game, then 2 next matchups were against clearly highly tuned decks full of legendaries that prevented me from doing anything. At the lowest rank. And I've been playing since last November, so I can only imagine how bad it would be for a newbie.Playing "draft mode" will let you expand your collection without facing overpowered decks, but, unlike previously, to get tickets for it you now have to beat aforementioned highly tuned decks, or pay money. If you do, you can eventually play constructed mode and smack people with lesser collections unless your client bugs out, I guess.I used to recommend this game, but unfortunately unless things are dramatically rolled back, it's a solid NO.

content:
Posted: July 6, 2016
Early Access Review
								The game mechanics are fun, the cards are interesting, and the art is very good looking.  I was going to spend some money on this game, and I wish I could recommend it.Unfortunately, the only way to grow your collection, is to either:A) Play against other players, 99% of which have hundreds of Legendary cards.     - This gives you a small amount of currency you will collect to have a small chance to get the cards you need.B) Spend a huge amount of money hoping to get some of these Legendary cards.     - This gives you a variable amount of currency you will use to have a small chance to get the cards you need.Which means that you are afforded the opportunity to learn how to play the game, and then presented with a wall of people who have either years worth of cards, or have spent $1000+ on being competitive.After the initial tutorial, you have no way to progress without spending 4+ hours a day trying to collect lucky wins or that rare game where you are matched with someone at your own level.

number of helpful: 20 of 35 people (57%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: August 17, 2014
Early Access Review
								Summary:Constructed: Pay to win.Draft: Fun.Let me tell you a story why you don't want to play constructed with a slim wallet.At the beginning, my starter deck was fine, I tried to make the best out of it with more or less success. Then I was lucky enough to open a Tarsus Deathweaver from a booster pack, forged 2 more, and built a whole new synergy-based deck around it. Only commons and rares, a couple of heroics and no legendaries. It worked literally awesome, I won 80% of my matches even against players with better cards overall. After a while, I felt, I'm being paired agains players who had spent a bunch of money to buy the same starter deck 3 times (since this is the most reliable way to get legendaries). Now, I can only win 20% of my matches because in the other 80%, my opponents present more legendaries in their first 4 turns then I have in my whole collection.You might feel tempting to buy legendary chests. Once you spend money on the game to play better constructed deck, you are part of the big grinding. The daily rewards are far not enough to get good cards. On the other hand, drafts are suprisingly good. The system works differently than anything else I've ever seen. You draft alone, which means no other players are involved in your draft procedure, thus you can draft in your own pace. Once you drafted the 30 cards, it becomes your deck and you are now ready to play your matches. However, you don't need to play them on the spot! Play them whenever you have time. If you're too tired in the evening, you can draft the cards and play the games on the next day or whenever you want. This means you  don't need to spend 1-2 hours to draft and play at the same time.

content:
Posted: June 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								As of 2/13/2015 the game is worse by the day, there is no balance to older cards, no external market, no campaign, still an ugly SNES-like interface and music, both the devs and most of the community seems to be in a denial state in which everything is "healthy" despite the last major tournament 13 out of 16 decks where the same one.The devs don't care about the community (there is only 300-give or take of us), I wouldn't want to imagine how it would be if it was a larger community. There is always an IMBA Nekrium card or more, the main reason I waited 5 months to update my review was to "give devs a chance to mature the game". and it just didn't happend despite false promises of "quicker balance".Draft is fun, the game engine and concept is fun, but poor design and balance kills it, there's a 4 color wheel but you only see the same one (Nekrium) with another as a sidekick, so don't bother with it. I won't even bother giving full details as to why gameplay is broken, as it's always one Nekrium card, this time it's Duskmaw, if you read my older entries you'll find out it was something else, like the previous one, broodqueen never got anything but a soft nerf, she still dominates games.So move over to some other TCG, don't waste your time like me, I'm too deep like to just leave it now.On a sidenote, Richard Garfield is no longer involved in this mess, he was in the initial design when it was balanced towards 3 out of 4 factions.***Previous review***As of 9/19/14 there's been a new update with a new set of cards, guess which side got the most OP cards? Nekrium! how surprising, on the bright side, SBE is finally doing some rights...Just some weeks after they finally nerfed Zimmus the unnerfying all the Nekrium fanboys thrown their Zimmus aside, but for them to be happy the guys at SBE decided to launch some more OP nekrium cards, so instead of getting beaten hardcore at Rank 3 you can get beaten badly at rank 1.These cards are broodqueen, doomrider and xithian direhound, I don't even bother, everytime I see my oponent playing any of the first 2 I know it's over, I just concede, it's POINTLESS to play UNLESS you got a VERY SPECIFIC Tempys deck that requires... more heroics, in other words $$$ or grind because I have yet to draw ONE of those heroics, set aside the idea of building a deck and pulling one in the right moment.The folks at SBE decided to "nerf" broodqueen by nerfing it's spare token, but it can still destroy any creature matching it's level by sacrificing any creature or token that player controls, the other 2 are left untouched.Card design is still as terrible and lazy as ever, there's this mechanic called overload you play a "very strong card" and then remove it from your deck, so meanwhile Tempys deals 8 damage and uterra gives +6/+6 to an allied creature and Alloyin does EXACTLY the same as an already existing rare without any other benefits (lets say the older rare metasight is better) Nekrium lets you debuff a creature for -5/-5 AND put a solid 5/5 into play, because Nekrium needs even more power right?On the bright side, SBE added a handful of achievments that can help new players get a legendary each time they reach a win milestone, it's very nice, but it's not enough for new players to catch up.Non-nekrium removal is as terrible as usual, it's hard-gated and still costs a lot of board advantage to get it to work properly, Uterra "removal" sometimes ends up benefiting your oponent rather than helping you.Tarsus is still as OP as ever, just some people forgot about him already due to the broodqueen frenzy, in the worst cases which are many, people combo Tarsus with broodqueen.The rewards where a little beefed up from 30 silver to 100 silver (a booster costs 5k silver) setting aside the generous 3 daily rewards which are the core for f2p players.So it's still a GREAT game, really the best among the free to play card games as far as mechanics go, but it's ruined by lousy balance and design.On another bright side, SBE recently started re-adjusting old commons and rares, I think this is great as starting players won't have as many useless cards as they did, IF they keep this trend of re-balancing the old cards I will say this is another great step for SBE, all they need to do is nerf the♥♥♥♥♥♥out of Nekrium cards and the game can be solid and enjoyable.It can improve, but we're VERY far away from a desirable state of game, it has a lot of potential, but right now it's still broken, if all classes where equally balanced I would say the game would be very enjoyable until then it's frustrating because most people rely on power-play.***Here's my old review***Okay, before you look at my hours playing it and say "but this guy enjoys the game", let me just warn you, I'm a masochist hence why I still play this, but you should avoid it.Solforge is a fun card game, but it has a huge problem, and that problem is balance, developers just sit self-entitedly making OP nekrium (a faction) cards while all the other factions remain gimped in comparison.All nekrium cards outclass any of the other factions, sometimes even combined, to the state where the game has become "play zimmus, you win".all nekrium fanboys sit in denial saying there are workarounds, and yes, there are many counters, the problem is they cost ALOT of card and position advantage.Picture this: you can play 2 cards per turn, if you play for example Alloyin you must play a disable (not even a removal) and then your creature and your 2 cards are gone, you must still kill the disabled creature someway and on top of it all, you must level up your disable if you want to use it on higher leveled creatures, if you didn't lost your card position advantage leveling the stupid disable, you won't be able to disable a higher level creature, meanwhile Nekrium has creatures with free removals or removals with free creatures, and the devs say it's fine.There's also the card inequality, meanwhile Uterra has a "target creature gets +3/+3" Nekrium has a "target enemy creature gets -4/-4 you gain 4 life" in a game where most creatures have 3 to 5 health it's an instant kill.There's an alloyin heroic that gives all enemy creatures -3 attack, there is another alloyin heroic that gives all allied creatures +3 attack making that casting 2 cards, but there is a Nekrium rare that gives -2 to all enemy creatures and +2 to all allied creatures in one card.Great design, props to Stoneblade.90% of the kids in this thing play Nekrium or splash nekrium as it's the easy way to get around, and they maintain their "everything it's fine" mentality, but it's not, even when the tournament deck winners are often not nekrium or just splash nekrium but they require alot of legendaries and that's microtransactions or time your choice, I won't say it's pay to win because it's not, you can grind your way out or you can pay your way out.Cards are easily available for everyone at the steep cost of $20 for one legendary or around a month and half of saving silver and not buying anything during that time, knock yourself out, the apologists will say "oh that's cheap compared to MTG" the difference is, a real MTG can be re-sold, these cannot.So we get a game with alot of powerplay, that doesn't reward creativity, high costs, and on top of that we get a lousy community with A LOT of AFKers holding your scarce wins back away from you, did I mentioned there is a lousy RNG too? yeah, sometimes you take a game leveling cards to never see them again while your oponent just summons their freaking godzillas twice, because every 4 turns the cards cycle back again.You should definitely avoid this, I'm too far inside like to come out that easily, but if you're looking into it, take a turn around, save yourself time and don't look back, and if this review gets alot of "not helpful" thats the fanboys in the community for you.

This is insane, how can you imporve your cards if you maybe only get 3 greens a day? So you have to pay. Nothing more, no campaing no nothing ( i dont count the PvCPU who is based only in the basic decks of the game and very easy to beat).You can have fun for the firts hours of gameplay, after that you crash to the wall who is the P2W and the game becomes much less fun.In resume, stay away and dont lose your time here.

content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												So after not playing the game for a super long time (like a year plus) I get an email from Solforge dev team saying "Hello Forgeborn,There are only 12 Hours left to get your free 1500 gold! This is something we've never done before and we don't plan to do again. There are no tricks, catches, or caveats. We are literally giving away thousands of dollars in currency just for logging in and playing. Have you gotten yours?"So I'm like, "why not, I enjoyed the game. I'll login, get a bunch of free money and try it out again, see if I like it." (1500 is a pretty good amount of gold from what I recall)Login and play some tutorial matches because it's so different from last time, plus there must have been some massive changes that were large enough to prompt people who haven't played in a while to take the tutorial. But I don't get any gold. Mind you I logged in. Thought it would be that simple, like a daily login and I get the gold. Tried logging out and logging in again, nothing. Tried playing other matches, nothing. Sent an email to the dev team and got this response three days later, two and a half days after the gold offer expired: "Hi,The gold was in the store for purchase at the cost of one silver."Would have been nice if that was actually explained in the email that prompted me to play the game again. Pretty sure after reading the rest of reviews that this experience can sum up the games changes over the past year and the general feeling that the player base has towards the devs and the changes implemented in the game itself. Left with a sour taste in my mouth. And the game's hella slower than I remember it too. :(Sad, because I remember liking the gameplay when I played it before. If there was a "maybe" recommendation I'd choose that, but I'm gonna have to side with no instead.

number of helpful: 20 of 36 people (56%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								Obviously you cant do much wrong on a free to play game, but waste your time.Thanks to short game length you do not need much time to figure out how much fun the game is to you, so it might  be worth a try.Still, there are certain aspects that make the game way less entertaining than other card games, which is the main reason i do not recommend it:1.) You draw 5 cards and select 2 of them to play. Each turn you draw 5 new cards.This leads to a situation where you cannot plan your next step, since you do not know which 5 cards you will draw next. This game mechanic drastically reduces strategic options in this game.2.) The 2 cards you play level up. After a certain amount of turns you have access to the leveled cards. Additionally, there are many cards that can snowball within a single turn. If you are simply unlucky not drawing your leveled cards ( or a viable counter), your opponent can snowball to an unbeatable situation quite quickly. This increases the RNG factor a lot, which is quite negative for a card game that already has a lot of RNG.3.) While this game is not actually pay 2 win (as you can get all cards for free over time), there are certain cards that are clearly better in all aspects compared to some of the cards you start with. Some cards are even unbeatable by the starting decks. Additionally the amount of free cards you can earn per day is limited.The game is much less enjoyable if you do not pay for it or grind for weeks to get the cards you need for a solid deck.So in the end.. it offers less strategy than other trading card games and is less casual as well, making other games clearly better.

number of helpful: 4 of 5 people (80%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 15, 2015
Early Access Review
								The good:There is pretty deep strategy to this game that isn't immediately obvious from the first couple of plays. It has some neat mechanics that I haven't seen in any other CCG.  I have 700+ hours on record, so it cant be that bad, or can it?The bad: ITS SLOWWWW: About that 700 hours.  A  lot of that time was spent playing other games or working while waiting on a slow opponent to take their turn.  Games take too long and players are slow. The only game mode is a 20 minute timer on both sides. Many players rage AFK when losing making you wait for 15 minutes to collect your win.  Many other players play so slowly they take their whole 20 minutes. This is really frustrating to me, as I rarely use more than 5 minutes of my time. NOT FTP FRIENDLY: Decks are 30 cards, and most top tier decks use 9 legendaries or more. That makes it very difficult for FTP players to be competitive. Spend money or you will be locked out of competitive constructed games.POWER CREEP: Power creep seems to be a real issue.  Every set has a couple of godawful broken cards that are then nerfed later on (after the paying player base got a chance to abuse them, of course).NO MARKET: There is no public market for cards, instead there is a trade system. Its okay, but a market would be much preferable. As it is now cards have little value. COPY_PASTA: Copy-pasta meta.  I have played CCGs quite a bit, never have I seen a meta so dominated by builds that are blatant copies of winning decks. It makes things really dull. SWINGY:  Recently the game has become much more swingy due to uber powerful cards and combos. By this I mean you may be 10 turns into a game, have your opponent locked down at every turn, ahead on life, ahead on board position, then suddenly you lose. Its pretty frustrating.I dont enjoy the game anymore.  I liked it the first hundred hours or so,  now I just play it due to inertia.

content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Edit: The day after I wrote this, the Varna expansion was released. Blatant powercreep, a lack of limitations on legendary cards, and ridiculous powers for those legendary cards has basically turned matches into the typical who-has-better-cards and curtailed the amount of strategy in the game. There is no purpose to owning any cards othen than the top 2 out of 5 tiers for the most part, with a few exceptions. Sadly, you'll only get a legendary chest about once a month as a free player, and considering the ridiculous price of a single chest, it's kinda tough to justify the purchase, especially knowing the next set will powercreep your collection out of the game. While I'm gonna stick around for a bit and hope the tide changes, it's pretty difficult to recommend right now. ~~~I've been pleasantly surprised by this game. While there is a power advantage to having rarer cards, there is enough of a synergy requirement, and a large enough playerbase, to prevent it from being too annoying thus far. The card-leveling mechanic is really engaging and refreshing. It adds progression to a CCG that isn't found elsewhere, along with another strategic layer. The small deck size (30) helps mitigate the odds of not drawing the card you want. This creats a slight negative in that deck variety is a little limited, but after 100 wins (which I reference because that's the achievement that just came up) I'm still excited to load up a match. The tounaments are a lot of fun, and seem to be pretty accessible (~2 per week as a free player, maybe more). I got in through the Humble Bundle, which gave me 2 starter decks, and I've been pretty competitive (though I wouldn't recommend buying the packs, as the cards have been powercreeped out), winning at least half my games, though I have a lot of CCG experience. The 4 factions have distinct styles, and seem very well balanced.The interface leaves a LOT to be desired, but it gets the job done. Hopefully it gets a serious makeover in the near future.

number of helpful: 7 of 11 people (64%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: May 7, 2015
Early Access Review
								Solforge is a card game with a new formula, and it's leveling up cards while playing a game.Each turn you draw 5 cards and you get to play 2 of them.When you play a card, you discard a higher level copy into your discard pile.Cards you don’t play get discarded themselves with their current level.PRO:+ Lots of different & beautiful cards + Updates also add new cards, besides fixes and so on.+ New idea of leveling cards is refreshing for a card game+ SAVING WHEN IN A CAMPAIGN MISSION: press return to menu, you can find your unfinished game in the play menu. Other (card) games can learn from this feature.+ Campaign is challenging, first some proving ground tutorials, then mastery games,… (winning a mastery gives you a legendary card of your opponent !)+ There are tournaments: constructed (your deck against another), draft (pick cards and make a deck), expert draft. (higher position in tournament, higher rewards) (Losing in a tournament still gives you card packs.)+ Some cards can be forged cheap (most of them are not)+ You earn cards& card packs by playing the campaign (also rare, heroic and legendary) (Yes, I got a lot of heroics and 2 legendary by opening packs the game gave me.)+ Daily rewards (win 1 game a day, win 3 games a day) will get you a card pack and other rewards (win online game, win 10/100/1000 online games) give you even more. 10 online games completed => legendary chest !+ First items from the store are at a discounted price, so you can buy these by playing a little ( got enough silver& gold &2 decks via a humble bundle)+ You can buy additional deck slots in the store.+ Price for card packs in the store is ok (but I never did) CON: - Booting up issues- Collection loading issues- Collection: the button to switch from list view to card view is hiding itself very good, took me a while to notice it.- The font used for the text is somewhat blurry, but you can adjust that. (But the text itself is nicely done.)- Very short campaign.- Mastery missions in campaign => excuse for the game to cheat on you, this wouldn’t work in real life ! Example: only 1 card may be played when you begin the match, they play 2,…- Decks, event tickets, legendary chests, daily cards, special packs, are expensive ! Even the ‘discounted chests’ are expensive.- Constructed tournament is pay to win, they all have superpower decks, including new cards you didn’t buy or legendary cards which are just too expensive.- Access to tournaments is expensive from 3-7 event tickets, to large amount of silver you can’t obtain by just playing the game, quantities of gold that require real money !- Alternative legendary cards not forgable, you can buy them in a daily rotation card scheme (card of the day), but this rotation scheme also includes normal legendary cards.- You can only break down a card if you have 4 copies of it.- Breaking/forging cards can be accessed by clicking on a card in your collection. Maybe say it somewhere in a tutorial ? Make an extra menu option for breaking/forging cards ?- Breaking/forging cards doesn’t really pay off. => expensive !There are better (Magic) and a lot more more renewing (Card City Nights) card games out there, try them instead.If you already played all other card games, you can try this game.Try the campaign and the drafting tournament.Avoid the constructed tournament, so you won't experience the pay to win story.I could play the game without paying, but then I realised I actually payed because I got Starter deck 1 & 2 & bonus gold from a Humble Bundle. I doubt you can fully enjoy the game without paying for something, but don't understand me wrong, the game also gives you cards etc.

content:
Posted: December 1, 2013
Early Access Review
								SolForge is an interesting take on the digital card genre. It's a fairly simplistic card game, but with a suprising amount of depth / theorycrafting to your decks once you've unlocked some cards. It has the unique aspect of your cards levelling up as you play them; adding a depth of strategy that other card games haven't really explored. Not only do you have to think about what card to play right now, in order to damage your opponent, or save yourself from damage, but you also have to think about the future - and which cards you'll want then and how your deck will evolve compared to their deck.The starter decks are playable, but I would strongly advise you to buy some packs (you can use silver which you can get from logging on daily and from winning matches) and get a custom deck going. You will get your♥♥♥♥♥kicked taking your cheap/free decks into PvP, but you can win your silver rewards playing against the AI - which is beatable on all difficulties with the starter decks, although the higher difficulties will be a challenge. If you do use real money to purchase packs, you will have a higher chance of getting the best cards, ultimately people should remember that card games are about spending money and RNG, but overall this is very playable as a free player too.One of the big advantages of this game right now to me is that the Ipad app is extremely fluid and responsive. You can play untimed games with friends and the push notifications are accurate - meaning if you have a lazy day with 5 minutes to spare here and there, you can have a good duel with your friend from anywhere. (Untimed) games save despite the application being shut down; and you can start a game on the ipad and continue it on the PC, or have the game running in two locations at once if you so desire. A lot of digital card games right now have promised this sort of cross platform interactivity, but few have competently provided it yet. The android app is sadly not out yet so I can't comment on that - but they have said there'll be one in the future.I'm pretty happy with it overall and would recommend.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 18, 2016
												Great game and the idea of transformation as the core makes gameplay fun and entertaining. I split most of my time playing CCGs between this and Hearthstone, which is also pretty great.Sadly the campaign in this game is incredibly broken. If all you'd like to do is play in online battles, then this game would be great for you as you can obtain great cards and content just playing online alone. However, if you wish to play the campaign it takes endless amount of time to devise a strategy to beat each individual boss. One of the most broken characters in the game is Cercee, who kills you in one hit after about 10-15 turns, every time, unless you have the proper card in your hand to prevent it. While accomplishable, it's infuriating to play against an AI that can defeat you with one card, even if you maintained all of your health up to that point. Each enemy campaign player also has passive abilities that you are never allowed to utilize as well. (I.E. whenever a creature hits you, destroy that creature. Whenever your creatures deal damage, gain that much health. All creatures have aggressive. etc.)(Cercee -> Whenever this creature deals battle damage to a creature or player, deal damage to them equal to their HP,)It would be far better if they would make a campaign that had a story to it instead of pitting you against incredibly broken enemies instead of fair fights in which they simply have better or equal cards and you need to out-strategize them.Sadly, in the campaign's current state (which is half the point of the game), I cannot reccomend this game to someone who is looking for a game to enjoy without requiring them to play against other people that will probably be willing to empty their wallet into getting the most OP cards.

number of helpful: 2 of 2 people (100%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 1, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have tried to keep an open mind since the big update that pretty much killed this game but in the end the game is just not as good as it used to be.  This is perhaps a perfect example of exactly how not to use an open alpha or beta. The developers put the nails in this game's coffin by releasing a whole new client as the 1.0. instead of using the open alpha to release incremental updates and get feedback. They scrapped the old game entirely and released a whole new one after an exceedingly long time of zero public updates.The new client is absolutely horrible. The new flashy animations are headache and eye strain inducing and detract from the gameplay. The game is buggy and unresponsive.  The update has pretty much removed everything that was conducive to bringing new players to the game. When I first started playing I had almost no cards and would lose almost every single pvp match but I was able to earn cards daily by playing the A.I. and now I probably win 75% or more of my matches. You can no longer earn rewards in non pvp matches so good luck getting started.The game log, which I use to use extensively is now mostly useless which will further alienate new players as it is now harder to understand what has happened in a match.Overall the game is just not fun anymore and probably on its way out with new players turned off by the ever increasing number of negative reviews. Developers take note, use the benefits of an open alpha/beta and don't make this same mistake.So to break it down, most of what this game had going that made it stand out as the best TCG out there is gone. I could go on for a while with the plethora of things broken by the update but I'll just end it here and uninstall.

content:
Posted: November 13, 2016
												This game contains the stupidest AI I have ever had the misfortune to play againt in a CCG. You start with 120 health and have to reduce your oponents health to 0 to win. On the HARDEST AI difficulty setting I have to play "kill the opponent without losing a single health point" for any sort of challenge, and even then I beat the AI 95% of the time... and this is where the AI and I are playing exactly the same deck.I understand the programming an AI to cope with so many cards can be a challenge, but countless other CCG games have done it without a problem. There are certain cards that get a bonus if they are placed in certain slots on the board but even if the board is completely empty and I have no creature in play that the AI needs to counter it still plays its creatures in the slots that WON'T get the bonus. If I have a creature with 11 damage and only 2 health left and all the AI has is small level 1 creatures, I have lost count how many times it refuses to sacrifice a 2 attack creature to kill my 11 attack creature but instead puts it in an empty row where it's not going to do anything, so I get to inflict 22 damage on the AI without issue. The AI is SO DUMB that when I'm playing my "end the game with 120 health" and I am below that number so I am waiting for healing cards to push my health back up I have to start replacing my OWN cards with new ones that won't attack until the turn after next because the AI is so stupid it plays cards in a way that would cause it to lose even on its hardest level.

content:
Posted: October 31, 2016
												I have been playing this game since the beta and first was amazed by the graphics and sleek design.The game has changed a lot with new cards being added, the built-in store offering more and tournaments being released.Now, that is not necessarily a bad thing.I could tell you about over-powered cards now that can dominate a whole game but let me assume that every strategy game has at least one of these.Instead let me tell you what I have noted as a casual and none-paying gamer:You start the game off with (naturally) weak cards and are being pointed to the campaigns that serve as tutorials and also offer stronger cards as rewards for completing them.So after you have mastered the first, let's say, four of them you might feel the urge to test your cards on the field against real players.Now this is where it goes wrong for me. No matter if you choose a ranked or un-ranked game, the opponent you face will have stronger cards than you. The change to win any game with just a handful of compaigns completed is about 1/10 if you are lucky.There are a couple of ways to get cards beside through the (limited) campains though:1. buy with real cash (easiest and most promoted as this is how this game is financed)2. complete quests (win 1 online game, play 4 games etc) to get game gold or random cards2.1. forge cards (requires game gold)Attention: I do not consider the tournaments here since I have not entered any. Reasons to be found all over the review.Now here is the funny part: You either have money to pay for cards and win (the greatest deal of) games against non-paying players resulting in more cards and game gold to forge and/or buy better cardsORYou do not have the money to pay yourself to victory and a strong deck. This means you have to play. A. Lot!This way you can at least get the daily quantity quest completed (play 4 games). Let's say one game takes half an hour and you only play 4 per day to get one rewards which is either 6 cards or a bit of game gold (of which you need 3 to 4 portions to buy 6 random cards). In each random card deck you get the chance at two higher ranked cards. To get there you need to put in two hours per day considered you do not get lucky and do win a game.Are you doing the math?If you are a hard-core player or one with a great budget, then this game could be something for you.The decision is all yours!

number of helpful: 3 of 4 people (75%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 6, 2016
												I REALLY want to give this game a good review, but...I just can't.Good:- The mechanics of the game overall are fun and easy to understand- The single player campaign helps learn how to play and provides cards to help make decks - The columns mechanic and the overall number of different mechanics in the game are fun and varied, allowing multiple playstyles- The game also has a fairly helpful and welcoming community.Meh:- The daily quests are helpful for getting some cards and tickets, but there's no variation at all in daily objectives. Might help to have some easier ones for new players (the 1 and 3 win ones can be nigh impossible for new players)- No trading (At least that I've seen). Makes collecting cards to make a half-decent deck to play with regularly that much harder and slower- Weekend events help with gaining cards, but still are heavily geared toward those with a vast library. It seems only 1 out of 3 events is one allowing the player to use cards they don't ownBad:- The curve to get into playing the game is steep. Unless you just don't mind taking your lumps getting beat a lot for a while until you can get some cards in your collection (like 6mo+ of it), expect to spend a fair amount- Their customer service is atrocious. I submitted a ticket about a problem with my account 2 months ago and heard back once about 3 weeks after. When I replied to the response, I've had no response since. Brough it up on their FB page and had the same response there. One person from there replied and been weeks since I've heard from them. Certainly makes me not want to spend any further time or money on the game- In a similar vein, it seems like there's very little contact from the company with the community (at least that I've seen). I get it's a smaller company, but nowadays, there's zero excuse not to have a community and/or social media manager to interact with the community.As much as I find the mechanics fun and different, I just can't recommend this game to new players until the company pays more attention to the customers and they can lower the overwhelming curve it takes to get into the game for new players.

number of helpful: 5 of 8 people (63%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
												SolForge - The DOTA of card games****************************************SolForge is that rare card game that can suck you in for countless hours with its unique gameplay. I have been playing this game for almost 2 years, and the new UI update has finally brought this game close to par with other competitors (atleast the pc version). The base concepts are simple, yet lead to so many different strategies. Deck synergies can make a heroic deck easily beat legendaries, and that is where this game shines. There is no one designated way to play this game, and a good levelup deck can drag a win out with 10 health remaining, and 1 turn away from loss. The satisfaction of dumping out a L3 Iron Maiden or Chrogias is just amazing.The gameplay has gradually gotten more polished over the last few years, and concepts like aggressive, mobility, vengence, flank, ambush, poison etc. keep old cards from fading into obscurity by coming back into gameplay with new deck synergies.Pros:1] Unique card levelling gameplay, where the weakest L1 cards become L3 behemoths, and L1 powerhouses become wimps at L3. Its all about deck planning, and identifying the right levels for a deck to peak at.2] Great card synergies3] Specific cards to run counter-strategies against cancer decks4] New game update finally makes games much faster5] Dailies give enough to start playing random draft eventually, and help build up silver to start forging specific cards.6] http://solforgegame.com/shop/ usually has a few prebuilt decks for new players, though for some inexplicable reason they aren't  available in the in game client anymore.7] CARD SHARING !!!Of course, SolForge does not come without a few cons as well, but they aren't so big that they affect the core gameplay, which probably in itself is a big win.Cons:1] Building a good free collection takes time, especially getting 3 drops of that 1 card you're looking out for. But this is inherent in any free to play game.2] Buying card pack boosters with gold (cash) can get expensive, especially when looking for something specific. It is a lot better to collect silver and forge cards, rather than hoping for a random drop from a booster pack.3] Offline wins against AI no longer completes dailies, thereby removing the easiest way to collect cards and silver.

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: February 22, 2015
Early Access Review
								When I first picked this up a few months back for an hour or so I shrugged my shoulders and tossed it aside (foolishly) having just spent a day or two on the vastly inferior bloodrealms I felt the similiarity of the lane style one card face off style fooled me into thinking they were the same game. I was wrong and the beauty and the simplicity of this game is that the choices you make early can completely change your end game strategy.As a CCG I will personally score this game highly because it breaks away from the Magic the Gathering formula that many recent ccgs are clutching to (Hearthstone, Hex). Though I love the game in the case of Hex, Shards of Fate, the best way I can put it is that they made some very basic and simple modifactions to MTG mechanics and cards and tweaked it to take advantage of digitial playing field. To be honest its nearly a blatant copy and some will hate on that but Hex took a great concept and made it better. Given that MTG has failed miserably and shamefully to be able to do the same with their own product I will just quitely applaud that the product is there to enjoy. I will however stand up and applaud louder when someone strikes out into some different territory and manages to make a few decisions (usually only two or three per turn) evolve into a complex web of moves and counter moves. There's alot here to love and I am ashamed I missed out on it the first go round.There are some weak points I will touch on but I would like to point out that there seems to be alot of hate in this review sections for this game that are centered around the "pay-to-win" aspect of this game. EVERY colletible card game has some element of this (Scrolls comes close but you can still get an advantage by tossing in some extra coin) and If your passing this one by because of all the hate you see in the forums or on the internet you are making a mistake. I paid absolutely nothing into this one for the few weeks and acquired a MASSIVE collection of cards to play with. There is plenty of fun to be had here without paying a dime. The worst thing far and away about this game is the User interface which I have found to be awkward and counterintutitive. There are achievments that can not be found anywhere in game which is a bit odd to me. The collection screen where you make decks is frustrating to say the least. This is a real shame because all the accessibility bonus the core mechanics offer to draw new people to the genres is lost pretty quickly when you can not figure out what is what after the brief tutorial.Overall Solforge offers something great from a mechanics standpoint and the f2p factor gives it a big boost for me (don't believe the hate).Recommended if your a fan of TCG's and want something a bit outside the box.7/10

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 2, 2013
Early Access Review
								SolForge is a very interesting digital CCG.  Those familiar with CCGs such as Magic might be skeptical about the lack of an explicit resource system, but the game manages beautifully without lands to pay for your cards.  The idea that you can play any card in your hand is incredibly empowering, but the knowledge that the cards you don't play will be discarded makes for agonizing decisions.  Each turn is a difficult balance between playing for short-term needs and long-term strategy.Cards can be bought with real money, but they're also handed out quite generously through simple play rewards.  One can earn the play rewards by beating the AI, and AI difficulty can be set to make the rewards trivial to obtain.  A downside is that there's nothing that can be done with duplicate cards, but I hardly find this to be a significant fault given how quickly it's possible to build a collection.Speaking of the AI, I'd never have put as much time into the game as I have if the AI wasn't interesting to play.  The Hard AI poses a reasonable challenge, and is great for quickly testing out deck strength.  Humans will always pose a better challenge, but the AI is good enough to making beating up on it fun, and if I can't beat it consistently then I know my deck needs work.I highly recommend SolForge.  It's a fresh design in a world where so many games are simply tweaked clones of those that came before.  It's fun, it's challenging, and it's free to try.  What more can you ask for?

number of helpful: 1 person found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 6, 2014
Early Access Review
								Solforge is a unique card game that stands out from competition in both gameplay and design. Cards in Solforge level up as you play them, from levels one to three, getting more powerful as they go. Decks are composed of 30 cards from 4 factions with no more than 3 of each card, the interesting part being you can mix and match from 2 different factions. Each turn you draw 5 new cards and discard your old hand, and you're allowed to play 2 of these 5 cards in any one of 5 lanes. After 4 turns your deck is reshuffled and every card you played is leveled up. The goal of the game is to get your opponent's life total from 100 to 0.Cards vary quite diversely as you would expect from any good CCG or TCG, there are direct damage spells, buffing spells, cards that allow you to play or draw more cards, creatures that are weak at low levels but extremely powerful at higher levels and vice versa. Within the Creature category there are many abilities they can possess, ranging from regenerating lost health, to having armor that detracts damage being done to their health, to ignoring summoning sickness that other creatures have, and much more.Gameplay is very fun and VERY strategic, although still occasionally plaqued somewhat by RNG as most other card games - however I find it to be completely managable. Balance is pretty decent, there are a few cards that are too powerful as you might expect, but nothing too drastic in my opinion. The main problem I see with the balance is that the rarest cards are, for the most part, the cards that make the biggest (and strongest) impact, the kinda cards you can build a whole deck around, which brings me to the Free-to-play aspect of Solforge.The F2P aspect of Solforge is probably where the game fails most in my opinion (although once again, nothing too bad). Card rarity varies from Common, to Rare, to Heroic, and finally Legendary. Common and rare cards are very easy to get, heroics a little harder, but legendaries are very difficult to come by. You can obtain cards by completing daily rewards for playing, purchasing packs with an in game currency, and of course using real life money to purchase packs/additional cards. I find the prices to be placed on these to be placed too high - HOWEVER, Stone Blade Entertainment (the creators of Solforge) are still testing the market and have definitely discussed lowering the prices, so in a few months they might be better priced.This segways nicely to the next topic of developer communication and commitment. The developers are very involved with the community as you might expect from a game that started on kickstarter, they have answered many questions and made balance descisions based on community feedback. Updates are pushed out decently quickly and I believe an 100+ card expansion is coming soon. Other things that are planned are a card "forging" feature, which will give a way for players with excess cards and in game currency to create the cards they still want, and a campaign mode to go along with the regular "constructed" and "draft" modes and I believe a trading feature.All in all a really great game that has the potential (and I think its potential will be filled) to be even better. In my opinion a real contender in the Online CCG market that is MOST CERTAINLY worth a try.

content:
Posted: November 14, 2013
Early Access Review
								I was never cool as a kid. Shocking, I know. I was always intrigued by table-top rpg's, and card duel games like Magic, etc. but never really had anyone in my social circle who shared the same interest so I never got into it.Which is why I'm probably really garbage at them now as an adult (except drunk d&d, I rock that!). Having said that though, this game is great. It might be more complex than I feel that it is, but it doesn't seem that way. It is nice and easy to drop in and figure out how to play, the rules are simple but the matches can be intense.The game has a few flaws, but unless you are die-hard over details, nothing you can't overlook to enjoy a quick match here or there. I recommend giving it a shot, since it's free you know, so why not? Hit me up if you do, and see if you can lose to me, since that's miles harder to do than win (against me that is).

After 4 turns your deck is reshuffled and every card you played is leveled up. The goal of the game is to get your opponent's life total from 100 to 0.Cards vary quite diversely as you would expect from any good CCG or TCG, there are direct damage spells, buffing spells, cards that allow you to play or draw more cards, creatures that are weak at low levels but extremely powerful at higher levels and vice versa. Within the Creature category there are many abilities they can possess, ranging from regenerating lost health, to having armor that detracts damage being done to their health, to ignoring summoning sickness that other creatures have, and much more.Gameplay is very fun and VERY strategic, although still occasionally plaqued somewhat by RNG as most other card games - however I find it to be completely managable. Balance is pretty decent, there are a few cards that are too powerful as you might expect, but nothing too drastic in my opinion. The main problem I see with the balance is that the rarest cards are, for the most part, the cards that make the biggest (and strongest) impact, the kinda cards you can build a whole deck around, which brings me to the Free-to-play aspect of Solforge.The F2P aspect of Solforge is probably where the game fails most in my opinion (although once again, nothing too bad). Card rarity varies from Common, to Rare, to Heroic, and finally Legendary. Common and rare cards are very easy to get, heroics a little harder, but legendaries are very difficult to come by. You can obtain cards by completing daily rewards for playing, purchasing packs with an in game currency, and of course using real life money to purchase packs/additional cards. I find the prices to be placed on these to be placed too high - HOWEVER, Stone Blade Entertainment (the creators of Solforge) are still testing the market and have definitely discussed lowering the prices, so in a few months they might be better priced.This segways nicely to the next topic of developer communication and commitment. The developers are very involved with the community as you might expect from a game that started on kickstarter, they have answered many questions and made balance descisions based on community feedback. Updates are pushed out decently quickly and I believe an 100+ card expansion is coming soon. Other things that are planned are a card "forging" feature, which will give a way for players with excess cards and in game currency to create the cards they still want, and a campaign mode to go along with the regular "constructed" and "draft" modes and I believe a trading feature.All in all a really great game that has the potential (and I think its potential will be filled) to be even better. In my opinion a real contender in the Online CCG market that is MOST CERTAINLY worth a try.

content:
Posted: March 15, 2014
Early Access Review
tl;dr: The game is fun and free, but expect to sink a decent amount of money into cards if you ever want to win matches.I really want to like this game. It's set up well, a lot of fun to play, and you don't need to sit down to an hour-long play session to enjoy a few games. The visuals are good, and the reward system for playing brought me back day after day.What killed it for me? The power differential: between the library of cards you amass from free play, and what you can purchase in the in-game Store. After months of daily play, I've put together a pretty decent deck. In random constructed matches, I win the vast majority of the time against decks with a similar number of Rare/Heroic cards. However, most random matches pair me up with players whose decks are suffused with Legendary cards (which have been purchased). In these games I'm consistently flattened, even when my opponent makes some serious misplays.If you've ever played MTG before, think of it in these terms: if you're not spending money, you're going to be playing a Pauper deck against top-tier constructed ones. If SB is going to continue this (which is perfectly valid, they're a company out to make money!), they might consider giving players the choice of seeking a random Casual match with low win rewards, or a Pro match with better rewards.If you're willing to spend money to win matches, go for it! It really is a lot of fun.

number of helpful: 3 of 5 people (60%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: November 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game has some very innovative and intriguing mechanics that differentiate it from the TCG genre. Principally the lack of any 'resource' generation and the 'leveling' of cards, allowing for more powerful versions to be played in later rounds. However, it suffers from three major flaws:1) If you are interested in deck building and/or competitive constructed play, don't bother unless you intend to throw down a significant amount of money, or are patient enough to wait (playing every single day) for several years (and even then, you likely won't have close to a full play-set of all the key cards you'll need to play at the top level).2) RNG is a massive determinant in games. While this helps keeps mediocre players 'competitive,' it's very frustrating to have game after game decided by a series of bad draws.3) Power creep. New cards are frequently just reprints of old ones with superior abilities, completely invalidating the older sets. Rather than augmenting existing decks or adding new and interesting folds to the metagame, they simply obsolete everything that has come before.Draft format helps with this somewhat, but without spending real money, you're only looking to play a handful of times per week.While these troubles aren't necessarily peculiar to this game compared to many other competitors in the TCG genre, it is enough to keep me from being able to recommend it.

content:
Posted: September 21, 2015
Early Access Review
								Having given this game a good couple of hours (spread over a few months, which makes it seem rather sparse), I feel confident in recommending it to others if only for the novel appeal.In short, drop cards like they're hot! The "Leveling" system for the cards puts a different spin on play-style, as well as the zero cost for playing them. The only cost you pay is the regret of having to discard the cards you didn't use but ended up needing. But that's all circumstantial and a bit easier to mitigate once you've a better grasp on the cards and mechanisms.That said, some cards might put you off at first. "Big whoop," you might say, unless it's within the first 'round' or two of hands and you realize, "Holy balls, the level-ups are incredible!" So yeah, drop those cards. Even if your ranks are full and the spells you have aren't necessary, it still pays to play *something* if only for the sake of getting a stronger version of it later, and you're on hand 3 of 4 in the round. And again, no 'mana' cost.It has a "snowball effect" appeal to it, I guess. Which can be refreshing. While I appreciate the cautious, long-haul strategy of Magic and similar card games a bit better, sometimes I like something with a faster pace and exponential growth - though I seldom see my level 3 cards.This is all online play notwithstanding. I base an assumption of "Legendary Stomping" on other reviews, and have had enough experience with Hearthstone to be frustrated by feeling incapable of beating anyone. Fact of the matter is, I'm a heavy gamer, but spread my attention across many games. I simply don't invest enough time in these F2P games to build a strong collection and be competetive. And that'd be a lame excuse to pay real life money, so I won't. If I get tired of playing against CPU and draft tournaments feel too noncommital after awhile, I'll just stop playing again.But again, fun game/concept and worth at least a small chunk of your time to try.
