number of helpful: 7 of 13 people (54%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: October 18, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm somewhere around 700-800 hours of playtime, since iOS progress isn't calculated. I've played the game DAILY since January 2014 on iOS, when the deck customization was implemented to the game.SolForge is one of the two actually proper digital card games around for the people looking for depth in mechanics. The other would be Battle Decks, not Hearthstone, but let's not go there now...-30 card deck-Draw 5 cards on each turn-Start with rank 1 (tech level in game)-Played card gets a leveled up version to your discard pile-Each rank consists 4 turns for each player-Discard pile and the rest of the draw deck gets shuffled when new rank (tech level) begins-Based on actual effects and combinations, instead of flat out power/health of the cards-Most of the cards are capped to rank 3, but these are few that have rank 4 as well (not necessarely better)The table consists 5 lanes. Creatures attack the players, which both have 100 health at the start. The goal is obviously to get that to zero. If there's a creature at the opposing lane, the damage is exchanged. The damage is permanent and not healed on turns.The reward mechanic is VERY fair for a F2P game. There are no premium only -cards.1) You get a booster (or better) reward as daily login and silver worth around ~333% of a booster.2) From a first daily win, you get a draft ticket worth 4 boosters.3) From a third win, you get a similar reward as daily login - booster (or better) and silver worth ~33% of a booster.4) Each win also gives you 250 silver, which is 5% of a booster price.5) With 3 draft tickets, you get to enter a draft where you KEEP the 30 cards you draft. On top of that, you play 4 matches and get better rewards depending on how you succeed. Minimum reward is 4 boosters on top of the 30 drafted cards, which eg. include all the legendary cards in the game.The only real downside is that the legendaries from the past few sets have been power creeped. Legendaries used to be very situational, but the fact that there are now quite a few lengedaries that work.I suggest you play the game on iPad. That works wonderfully.The developer said that there should be a massive overhaul to the UI this autumn, but not quite sure if they'll make it.Highly recommended.

number of helpful: 9 of 17 people (53%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 19, 2014
Early Access Review
								While the central mechanics are interesting, they feel poorly put together. Each turn is basically a coin toss as to whether or not you will be able to do anything good. While strategic play can influence this to a point, the fact that you discard what's left of your hand and draw a brand new one each turn makes planning ahead difficult, not to mention that going several turns drawing level-1 cards which no longer have any impact once the stronger level-2 and level-3 cards appear is incredibly common and will often lead to losing any advantage you may have had, if not to losing the game outright.Aside from the fact that luck is far too great an element in this game, the balancing is an issue as well. Having spend 150 hours of in-game time on this game, I managed to acquire a grand total of 3 legendary cards and there were plenty of heroic cards I hadn't even seen at that point. At this point, I feel like I should mention that not only are the interesting effects mostly limited to legendary and heroic cards and many (if not most) deck archetypes are completely based around them, but in the few cases where they can be compared to the less rare cards they are almost always better. Who'd rather have a nexus core than a thundersaur? Who could make a removal deck without dreadbolt, a lifegain deck without Oros/Arboris or a metamind deck without Drix? Why is Chrogias better than scrapforge titan, echowisp better than ether hounds, hinterland watchman better than cypien infiltrator, etc?When we take the combination of poor balancing, slow releases, and the always overhanging element of luck and then add a UI that would've looked bad in 2005, the fact that card effects trigger in a random order, the fact that there is no reason to play more than 3 games a day, locking drafts to an average of 6 games (not 6 drafts, 6 GAMES) a week if you win half your games, the poor matchmaking and the frequently exploited fact that there are no turn timers - only a chess clock of 20 minutes, we get a game with interesting basic mechanics but unspeakably poor execution.While the review says I don't recommend this game, I actually recommend that you play this ONCE if you're intersted in TCGs, because the mechanics at the base of SolForge are actually fairly interesting and might change some things you take for granted in a TCG. But I do not recommend playing more than that and I beg you not to spend money on this. SolForge might be worth returning to one day, but do not expect that day to come anytime soon.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I see people mostly refer to missing features, stuff like ranked MP which is so obviously missing but as far as I understand is in the process of creation. Being an EA game (something should change here, EA game means something evil and should not be attributed to early access games) I guess missing stuff is normal. Even though, IMO ranked MP for games like these is a core feature, not something one should plan to implement at a later date. Right up there with "make an online gameplay system" regarding priority.My gripe with this game is its economy system. I simply have to compare it with Scrolls because there are many similarities. I'm personally not that much into competitive play and in this regard this game really doesn't offer much, past some OK campaign missions and a sub par AI with 0 rewards. Collecting cards and building decks would be interesting to me, had it not been for some problems.So, in scrolls you had (at the time I still played the game a few months back)- 360 cards in 4 factions- possibility to make some 1k gold daily, with a few daily trials and maybe one AI match. 1 hour tops, doable in 30 minutes.- with 1k gold you could purchase a pack of ten random cards, of which one was guaranteed to be a rare card and another two were uncommons. There was also a chance of about 10-20% to receive an 11th, higher tier card.- standard decks typically require one faction so upon choosing your color you practically had a pool of 90 cards from which you could choose.- most expensive cards on the market went for about 1800 gold, which in effect would be an equivalent of 5 LOST online matches, something like 2 hours of your time.- as long as you managed to put up a decent fight, online losses were rewarded nicely. AI matches were also rewarded, less handsomely, but the same principle applies - more fighting means more gold.- there were precon decks which went for 5k and 8k gold so all in all, if you wanted to build a specific deck you could do so without grinding to death. Say, two hours daily for a month should net you 60 to 80k with which you can build almost any deck you want. If you were good in competitive play you could net even more easily.In SolForge you have:- around 570 cards, not really sure how to check the grand total nor how many are there per faction since the interface is lacking in some regards.- easy daily rewards which require three victories against anyone, netting about 2.5k silver, two packs containing 6 random cards and a ticket which you need for online events. This requires about a half an hour of your time, if you played against easy AI probably doable in 15 minutes.- these packs guarantee only one rare card and offer a decent chance of getting some heroic and legendary cards. The problem is you are getting 6 from a pool of ~570. Compared to 10 out of 360 from Scrolls, which also gave one highest tier card guaranteed, this is quite bad.- to make things worse, forging prices are rather high. Common cards go for 150, rares go for 1400, heroic 32500 and legendary 142500 silver. If you decide to build a specific deck with say 15 heroic and 15 legendary cards you will need 2625000 silver which is an equivalent of about 1000 days of daily rewards.- online victories net 250 gold, max 10 daily I think so that could split above 1000 to 500 days of grinding, but with a lets say more significant time investment.- there are preconstructed decks for purchase and a sharing system so that, as long as you can find someone with whom you might share, you can cut deck costs to about $5 a piece.- there is also the option to earn some cards in the drafting portion of the game, which seems interesting and I'd like to get to know the cards a bit better before getting into that. You can play one casual draft match every three days for free, as things stand now.All in all, it is my opinion that, as a card collection game, SolForge sucks due to a bad business model. IMO. Even more so for new players.I'll update this after getting some drafting experience, maybe that can change my opinion dramatically.

								I liked this game and played it a lot till the 4-Level Card Addition which is unbalanced and a bad idea of more ranks more fun(if you pay)which gives no room for game knowledge instead it rather adds unbalance to the current game state.Deployed cards can be intuitive and predictable your oponnent will deploy the same card but it will be upgraded depending on the rank now 4-level can be easy to deal with but most of them are 1-hit kill if they reach such level.The huge variety of cards made the game attractive to me at first(i didnt wanted to try solforge i always wanted HEX but its on beta) dont let this fool you it just adds more fancy effects to your deck but there is no actual balance or skill involved on this.You can win a game with just yellow/red(legendary epic or whatever) in your deck and do nothing more than drag cards to the board and you will still win that easy.

content:
Posted: March 30, 2015
Early Access Review
								Reading other reviews: Most complaints revolve around being supposedly pay-to-win. It's a TCG. Compare it to an IRL one, where you HAVE to pay money (often LOTS of it)  to increase your collection, and it becomes FAR less so. Another is RNG. I've seen a few cards that use a "gain between 1 to 20 health" and similar, but frankly it doesn't detract that much from the game as you're just as likely to roll crap as you are fantastic.Start out facing the weakest AI level, build up your collection a little bit at a time. When you have collected 3 Event Tickets, start doing the Casual Draft - you keep the cards you draft, which will often include half a dozen Heroics, and are guaranteed at least 3 booster packs after you've played 4 matches with that deck. It's the fastest way to boost your collection. Don't bother buying booster packs with your earned silver, you can collect enough of those by playing, save it up for a Legendary chest.One thing I wish would be implemented is an inbuilt chat and trade function: maybe it's already there but I haven't seen it. Cross-platform is cool too, but the game runs like♥♥♥♥♥on my tablet anyway so whatever.

content:
Posted: April 1, 2015
Early Access Review
								For a free to play game, I have already spent $40 to buy gold.  This game is very fun if you enjoy games like Hearthstone or MtG.  Despite it's many bugs (constant crashing, having to reinstall the game every time a new patch comes out, inability to edit decks without the game freezing on my andriod device, etc) I will continue to play this game until they release a group of cards that are too broken and ruin the fun of the game.  The newly released campaign mode makes the game instantly accessable to new players, offering a way to expose you to deck ideas and collect heroic and legendary cards early with only a couple of thousand silver worth of cards.

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 27, 2015
Early Access Review
								I see people mostly refer to missing features, stuff like ranked MP which is so obviously missing but as far as I understand is in the process of creation. Being an EA game (something should change here, EA game means something evil and should not be attributed to early access games) I guess missing stuff is normal. Even though, IMO ranked MP for games like these is a core feature, not something one should plan to implement at a later date. Right up there with "make an online gameplay system" regarding priority.My gripe with this game is its economy system. I simply have to compare it with Scrolls because there are many similarities. I'm personally not that much into competitive play and in this regard this game really doesn't offer much, past some OK campaign missions and a sub par AI with 0 rewards. Collecting cards and building decks would be interesting to me, had it not been for some problems.So, in scrolls you had (at the time I still played the game a few months back)- 360 cards in 4 factions- possibility to make some 1k gold daily, with a few daily trials and maybe one AI match. 1 hour tops, doable in 30 minutes.- with 1k gold you could purchase a pack of ten random cards, of which one was guaranteed to be a rare card and another two were uncommons. There was also a chance of about 10-20% to receive an 11th, higher tier card.- standard decks typically require one faction so upon choosing your color you practically had a pool of 90 cards from which you could choose.- most expensive cards on the market went for about 1800 gold, which in effect would be an equivalent of 5 LOST online matches, something like 2 hours of your time.- as long as you managed to put up a decent fight, online losses were rewarded nicely. AI matches were also rewarded, less handsomely, but the same principle applies - more fighting means more gold.- there were precon decks which went for 5k and 8k gold so all in all, if you wanted to build a specific deck you could do so without grinding to death. Say, two hours daily for a month should net you 60 to 80k with which you can build almost any deck you want. If you were good in competitive play you could net even more easily.In SolForge you have:- around 570 cards, not really sure how to check the grand total nor how many are there per faction since the interface is lacking in some regards.- easy daily rewards which require three victories against anyone, netting about 2.5k silver, two packs containing 6 random cards and a ticket which you need for online events. This requires about a half an hour of your time, if you played against easy AI probably doable in 15 minutes.- these packs guarantee only one rare card and offer a decent chance of getting some heroic and legendary cards. The problem is you are getting 6 from a pool of ~570. Compared to 10 out of 360 from Scrolls, which also gave one highest tier card guaranteed, this is quite bad.- to make things worse, forging prices are rather high. Common cards go for 150, rares go for 1400, heroic 32500 and legendary 142500 silver. If you decide to build a specific deck with say 15 heroic and 15 legendary cards you will need 2625000 silver which is an equivalent of about 1000 days of daily rewards.- online victories net 250 gold, max 10 daily I think so that could split above 1000 to 500 days of grinding, but with a lets say more significant time investment.- there are preconstructed decks for purchase and a sharing system so that, as long as you can find someone with whom you might share, you can cut deck costs to about $5 a piece.- there is also the option to earn some cards in the drafting portion of the game, which seems interesting and I'd like to get to know the cards a bit better before getting into that. You can play one casual draft match every three days for free, as things stand now.All in all, it is my opinion that, as a card collection game, SolForge sucks due to a bad business model. IMO. Even more so for new players.I'll update this after getting some drafting experience, maybe that can change my opinion dramatically.

content:
Posted: April 5, 2015
Early Access Review
								SolForge is a fast-paced, balanced and thrilling new experience to the world of virtual card games. While the concept is not relatively new, SolForge introduces several simplified yet intriguing effects and mechanics, chief of which being the "rank up," giving incentive to play cards in certain orders.The game allows you multiple packs daily, and already offers a broad range of campaign missions with challenging objectives and vast possibilities, not to mention the tournaments. No matter what you pursue, there will never be a moment of low activity or a lack of others to play with.Exciting, fresh and unique, SolForge is a must-have up-and-comer on the digital CCG scene, and being free-to-play, offers no excuse not to give it a chance.

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								Back in January, I was a relatively new Hearthstone player who was also relatively new to card games in general. I was watching Brian Kibler's stream when he mentioned he was a developer for another free to play collectible card game: Solforge. He spoke a bit about it and I was intrigued enough to check it out.Now, in April and having played Solforge for a few months, I think I can speak enough about the game to warrant a review. Solforge has four factions and hundreds of cards. Games are played with creatures and spells, the former being placed in any of the five lanes and the latter having various effects. Creatures in lanes will "battle" opposing creatures in the same lane. If they are unopposed, they attack the player, removing a given amount of base HP. The first player to drop to zero, naturally, loses the game. As cards are played, they are discarded and "leveled", and when a rank is gained, the discard pile is shuffled and becomes the draw pile.If you enjoy CCGs, you will *probably* enjoy Solforge. It has a generally great community, many of whom are always willing to share cards with new players to help them get on their feet, which is really important because, as with any CCG, new players begin with an inherent disadvantage as all the veterans have more cards. This is something that all CCGs struggle with, and not even Hearthstone has a solution for it. Another thing to note is that the developer, StoneBlade Entertainment (SBE), seems to really enjoy ridiculously strong cards. They update often (new cards, nerfs/buffs, etc), but in the few months that I've played they've nerfed some strong cards while leaving other glaringly, fun-suckingly strong cards like Wegu untouched. The card Herald of Destruction recently received a massive buff that makes it as un-fun to play against as Wegu. Luckily (?), there's no ranking system, so games can be conceded without a second thought when you discover your opponent is running one of those decks. (Caveat: beware that complaining about cards will occasionally be met with "get better" replies or other variants of the same thing from veterans who have played the game since Kickstarter and will defend all of SBE's decisions to the death)Solforge has some incredible art, like the Byzerak Frostmaiden[hypershotgaming.com] and the Cindersmoke Wyvern[i.imgur.com], and some pretty bad art, like the Weirwood Ranger[solforgespain.files.wordpress.com] and the Tarsus Necrolord[www.ghoxssocks.com], though apparently many of the latter cards are from the Kickstarter, where backers were somewhat poorly photoshopped onto cards.I would be remiss if I didn't mention the incredible Kaelari and his unofficial Solforge Ladder[solforgeladder.com], where you can chat with other players, participate in tournaments of various kinds (the best are the unheroic and unlegendary ones, where the really strong cards that new players won't have are "banned") for different prizes, set up trades, and actually participate in a ladder ranking system. Most of the stuff that Kaelari's site does should ideally have been done by the developers themselves as opposed to an unpaid third-party, but SBE is seemingly more focused on pumping out cards than they are with smoothing out what they already have. There is a downside to this ladder, however, and it's that most of its users are veterans, so if you queue up for a ladder or tournament game, it's very likely the person will be better than you. Other than release day for new sets of cards, the number of people who concurrently use the Ladder sits around 50. That means that if everyone's queued (which is never the case), you've got a solid chance of playing the same person more than once. Not enough of Solforge's several hundred daily users either know about the Ladder, or care enough to use it, which is a damn shame, and it'd probably be a different case if it wasn't third-party. Indie developers only have so much money, though.As I said, I think StoneBlade needs change the focus from more new cards (which everyone loves), to doing things like meshing most of the Ladder's features into the game, overhauling the UI, and actually advertising the damn game. That being said, I'd still be hesitant to label this an Early Access game if it weren't for the big blue label on the store page (otherwise it'd just look like an indie game). Despite all its flaws, I do enjoy Solforge a whole lot and I implore you to give it a shot if you're even remotely interested. It's easier to get into than Hearthstone, as packs and cards in general are easier to acquire. SBE recently revamped the Draft (Arena) queue, where now you can pay 2 event tickets (acquired from your first win of the day) to draft 30 cards that you KEEP after the tournament, which is a fantastic value for new players.

content:
Posted: September 28, 2015
Early Access Review
								So far I'm really enjoying Solforge. As an avid TCG/CCG player, I managed to get right into the game, and the level mechanics really appealed to me. So far, my competetive experience has been pretty enjoyable, though matches can be a bit quicker (level wise) than I'd like. However my major bugbear is the timer. There is simply too much abuse on such a long duration, that It quickly destroys the enjoyment of a match. I would have to say 8/10, with the possibility of increasing with changes to the timer, and a larger cardpool.

number of helpful: 5 of 10 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												As you can see from my hours played, I love this game!The New client isn't perfect (yet) and yes, there are some issues, but most of them have workarounds for now.The basic gameplay is very easy to learn, but the more experience you get opens up a lot of deeper strategy.I've only put in 100$ after 4 months to jumpstart my collection when I knew this game was for me, and now I've got a full collection + for the next 2 years I'm probably safe to buy any card with the free ingame currency (Silver) and I've accumulated enough Even Tickets (from doing your Dailies) for the next 3 years.I'm not a top player (not by a longshot), but if you know a bit what you're doing and use your free resources wisely, you can get pretty far (there are some guides out there), but as with all ccg's, money gets you there faster.There's an awesome fanmade community site with extra Ladders (Standard, Unlegendary, Unheroic and Sealed) + free tournaments with prize support, a live chat and trading interface + a lot of people willing to help new players (http://solforgeladder.com/page/faq) There's lots of interesting and fun cards, a ton of fun decks to be brewed.The ingame Draft lets you keep the cards, so this is the best way to grow your collection and it only requires 4 Event Tickets (you get 3 by just doing your Dailies) and if you win 2 games you already get 1 ticket back, so it's quite possible to draft daily for free.Every Thursday to Sunday there are Weekend Warrior Events, ie tournaments with special rulesEach month there are Elite Events with awesome prizesThere's an inclient LadderPermanent Constructed and Draft queuesI really can't agree with the supernegative reviews on here, sure not everything is peachy but the core gameplay is awesome and very different from other ccg/dcg's and overall the game is very playable and enjoyableThe Daily Rewards are quite generous and there's lots of stuff to keep you busyThe biggest issue imo is the relatively small playerbase right now (altho I've never had a problem finding a game in any of the queues), so it's a bit tough for new players in the beginning, lately there's been an influx of fresh blood but we always need more, so come join us, it's completely free to try out :)

number of helpful: 1 of 2 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 22, 2014
Early Access Review
								The great thing about early access is that sometimes games actually change for the better and Solforge is one of those rare games to do so.Initally I had a bad run with the game which is pointless to talk about now since those issues are mostly gone now.I really like the systems Solforge has in place, such as leveling up cards during the match which adds a 3rd layer to the game. A card might be bad now at Lv1 but during the match it might be better at Lv2 so do I play it now in order to level it up or do I stick to my better cards now?Their is a lot I would have to explain about the game in order for this review to make sense and honestly even then it would sound confusing so you are better of trying this game out if you like card games.Their is an active player pool still playing even after 2 years and the game is taking the usual cardgame routes in terms of playstyles but the in-match leveling system really sets Solforge apart from its competitors and that is probably why Solforge is still going strong.Solforge is not for everyone, it is middle of the road as far as card games go but it is still young and the expansion packs have really shaken up the formula for how you play this game because originally it had some flaws to put it mildly whereas now it is a deep and engaging experience both creating and playing your deck.As far as I am aware, ELO rating is not implemented yet which I am fine with because matches give no rewards. Win 3 games per day (even against AI, or oddly even from the AI fighting itself) and thats it for the day. No more and no less. The game does have a cash shop, its free to play so of course it does but outside of that everyone is pretty limited in how many cards they can farm a day and while that is okay it does also make playing feel kind of hollow at times because you may need a card to finish your planned deck and after your three wins of the day you are out of options.Or you can pay, of course. Even if you do though their is no in-game ladder showing who is #1 etc and while that may be planned in the future if you are the kind to spend money on games like this be aware that you don't get any kind of trophy to show for your wins but on the flipside if you are not very good at card games then no one can see your low rank in this game so you are classed as equal amongst your peers which is a rare oddity in a competitive game. Matches are too random though so the game is terrible in the face of its competition.Join Grumpy reviews for all your gaming needshttp://steamcommunity.com/groups/grumpyreviews

number of helpful: 2 of 4 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 5, 2013
Early Access Review
								This is a card game in transition, and stone blade entertainment is trying their best to move this product towards completion, but it's not there yet. So consider this a review of a very half-finished game. The game is VERY rewarding for playing. A good 10 minutes a day is all it requires for you to farm yourself some excellent currency and a chance at packs of cards that go from poor (3 cards, one rare) or amazing on a seemingly very random process. The balance of the game is a "work in progress" to say the least with some factions having some seemingly near impossible creatures to answer. The investment necessary to kill those cards is so high that you put yourself too far behind to do much of anything against the lesser threats that still kill you. The game pace is great for quick games, and I think there is definitely a niche for this card game in the digital trading card game market, but they need to move quicker to solidify their position with a completed game before games like hearthstone and hex completely lock them out. The one thing as you may have gotten out of this review so far is that the game is truly free to play. You can be very successful in gathering cards with only investing time, and perhaps if there is actually a criticism, it is that they are giving you very little reason to play living opponents at this point. All in all, this game is headed in the right direction for a mobile digital card game especially and for that, this game gets a thumbs up from me.

number of helpful: 16 of 32 people (50%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 23, 2013
Early Access Review
								Solforge is broken to the core. With the player drawing a new hand each turn, and cards not having any cost (You play two per turn, plus extras if you have a free to play card), the game comes down to just what you would expect. Turn tactics. No long term tactics.To put it simply, building a deck in any other card game is about figuring what cards work well together, planning out for certain events and counters. Solforge? Its more about filling your deck with as many "Good" cards as possible. There is some thought to be hard, with certain cards working well with spells or deck types. But when you get down to it, the game is all about having the more rarer cards.This system itself is nothing new to card games. Nearly all of them run on the "If its rarer, its better" game. However, in a game without hard counters, no saving your cards for later turns, and entire hand wipes each turn, and on top of that, no card cost? It all ends up being a very messy, "Pay to win" style of system values the quality of your cards, and your luck, far more than the effectiveness of the deck.Putting aside the game rules for a second, we get to the more (And only, in my opinion), positive aspects of the game. The dev team are oddly running a double sided blade. The game is one of the most unfair, poorly balanced card games I've set my sights on.. Yet you can't fault them on their ethics. Everything you need, you can earn for free via three rewards daily (Logging in, winning your first, and third game). With the devs planning on adding silver rewards directly from online wins. If you found yourself a fan of the game, you'd seemingly at least be in good hands. Solforge doesn't make you feel the need to put money into the game. However, you'll soon find yourself wishing to do just that after experiencing the system itself.With the likes of Hearthstone, Magic, the up coming Hex and the countless other card games around, digital or otherwise, I see little reason to bother with Solforge.

content:
Posted: November 27, 2013
Early Access Review
								My review of Solforge used to be longer, and sort of confusing. That, and my impression of the game has changed quite a bit, so I decided to delete the old review.The core mechanic of Solforge, card leveling, is incredibly unique, to the point that a lot of people won't grasp how it affects deckbuilding and gameplay for a very long time. While SolForge seems like it doesn't have much strategy, it is actually incredibly deep, and every turn has very intricate decisions. You have to balance the desire to not fall behind on the board with leveling the cards that are going to help you win later. Using your life as a resource is imperitive when you are behind, and choices such as choosing the correct empty lane to put a creature into can be incredibly important. Tight play is rewarded very well in SolForge.Deckbuilding is also incredibly deep. You see your entire deck every game, which allows for narrow but powerful cards to be included in decks. When building, you have to plan the entire arc you want to follow in game. Do you plan to play very aggressively with powerful level 2 cards, or do you fill your deck with insane level 3 creatures, and build the rest of the deck to buy you time to get them out?The leveling mechanic makes drafting SolForge incredible. Every game I play with draft decks feels unique, since different cards get leveled, based on what my opponent was playing. In short, in a lot of ways, SolForge is too clever for its own good. The game's design is super simple, but the leveling mechanic has a ripple effect on strategy. I have so much fun brewing decks every day.

number of helpful: 4 of 9 people (44%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 15, 2013
Early Access Review
								SolForge is another entry into the recently-full group of Collectible Card Games, but it takes a fresh and unique approach to the otherwise-tired genre. Gone are the typical Magic:the Gathering clone features -- it removes the single card draw at the start of the turn, the 60 card deck slot, and even the concept of a graveyard. Instead, you get an incredibly deep, strategic system that demands you plan ahead, but flexibly (since RNG is still going to determine which cards you see).The most interesting part of the game is also its core: the cards you play level up each time you play them, to a maximum of level 3. Each time you level a card, it gets more powerful, sometimes exponentially so. But what makes this more strategic is that every 4 turns you reshuffle your played or discarded cards back into your deck. Since you draw 5 cards a turn, you're seeing 2/3 of your 30-card deck every 4 turns. It adds an insane level of consistency to your draws, if you plan accordingly.All in all, it's a game that's got a lot more depth than your typical CCG, and it is entirely Free-to-Play if you're willing to take a beating at first. (It takes about a month to really build the card pool based on the current daily rewards, but they're working to improve that too.) Definitely worth looking into!

content:
Posted: January 5, 2014
Early Access Review
								It makes a valiant attempt truth be told and it does try a few unique things but alas it falls short of the gold standards of MTG and Yu-Gi_oh. The fact that your hand resets after every turn removes a very key strategic element from the game, the ability to plan. Combined with the 0 play cost of any card each round is essentially each player slapping their 3 most powerful cards in hand down.Admittedly there's random chance in all card games but imagine if you will a poker game where after each round everyone discards all the cards in their hand, shuffles them back into the deck and draws a new set of cards; It'd pretty much knock out many important strategic elements of the game. IN this game simply, there's no reason to not play your most powerful cards which is the frist sign that strategy has been pushed to the side in favour of fast games. In MTG there are very good reasons not to play your super cards, because you have to figure what sort of cards the opponent might be having that'll pretty much destroy opr turn the card against you. Moreso in YigiOh because of the trapcard system, here, none of that exists.Is the game enjoyable? Yes, to a point, and that's about the point when you realize winning or losing is basically a dice rolls. Imagine a game where each player takes turns rolling a dice, the first one to accumulate a total of 30 wins. Such a game can be fun and nail biting yes but in the end it can be rather unsatisfying because your actual input in the victory as the player is minimal.A good game for those who want to test the genre of COllectible Card Games but for seasoned experienced players, skip this one.

number of helpful: 3 of 7 people (43%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												This game is interesting. I wouldn't say it's particularly complex as far as card games go, but it has some fairly unique and compelling mechanics such as the central mechanic of continously discarding and "leveling up" your cards.For new players, the game presents something of an uphill battle. Your best allies in this battle will be the daily quests, campaign, and the Draft tournament mode. The daily quests give a bit of currency and the occasional booster pack, and also event tokens you can use to enter Draft tournaments. (You get 3 tokens daily, Draft costs 4 tokens. If you get at least 2 wins, you get at least 1 token back, so it is possible to do at least one draft daily if you do well). The Campaign mode of the game serves to teach new players how to play the game, and gives some rather nice rewards to get your collection started, including some packs, currency, and a couple very solid cards.The Draft mode is perhaps unusually generous, you not only get rewards based on your number of wins, but you actually keep the cards you drafted. After completing the Campaign, rinding out this mode should be the primary goal for new players, imo. Sadly, the constructed deck side of the game is Pay2Win AF:1. Generally speaking, Heroic and Legendary cards are objectively more powerful than lower rarity cards, and2. You can have up to 3 copies of any Heroic or Legendary card in your deck, same as any Common card.This results in the best decks being composed of multiple copies of high-rarity cards that quite simply overpower opponents that can't afford to do the same. Particularly in the ranked ladder you'll run into nothing but people playing legendary after legendary. The game is free to play, and if you like card games there is definitely some enjoyment to be had here, but don't expect to get very competitive with it if you don't pay up or grind for a year or two. And if you choose to pay up, don't expect it to be too cheap, either. A "monthly discount" offers 10 booster packs for $5, And the only guarantee in such a booster pack is a Rare card, which are cheap to craft and generally quite underpowered compared to Legendary cards. And no, sadly Heroic and Legendary cards are not remotely close to cheap to craft. A rare costs 2500 Silver (in-game currency), a heroic is 25,000, and I don't even know how much a Legendary is since the 50k I've saved up over ages of playing this game isn't even enough to see the price. :')Booster pack costs 7,500 silver, and you can only buy the basic booster with Silver, recent expansion boosters are real-money currency only. The daily quest that gives silver is like 2500 I believe. I've read it costs 100,000 Silver to craft a Legendary card. So that's quite a bit of change to craft one card, and you'll likely need 3 copies.. plus 3 copies of several others.Rarity for this game goes: Common < Rare < Heroic < Legendary.As for a recommendation.. Running into people with full Legendary and Heroic decks can be a very frustrating experience, and I've played quite a bit of this game, have a few Legendary cards of my own.. but you playing the occasional Legendary just doesn't compare to a unified, themed deck running multiple copies of all the best cards. But even despite all that, I can still go back and try some new card combinations, make a new deck, and overall just enjoy myself for a while. And the game is free to play after all.. so even though I believe the ranked ladder is P2W.. I'm going to say yes, I would recommend trying out this game. It's also available on mobile devices so that gives it some bonus points. (As an update after spending all the tokens I'd saved up on drafts, all my silver on packs and crafting a few cards, etc.. I do find myself with the knowledge and a decent enough deck (or two) to climb the ranked ladder to some degree. But, I did have the advantage that some time back I bought a Humble Bundle deal that included 2 of the DLC decks for this game, and having those extra cards does definitely help). Anyway.. Yeah, the game can be fairly entertaining. Give it a shot.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2013
Early Access Review
								I signed up for the Early Access for Sol Forge but ended up being unable to play it on my PC unfortunately because it runs into a DEP windows error which I have been unable to solve and the DEVs said they would look in to it but never got back to me. I can only assume it isn't common enough to be worth their time to figure out what it is. After trying a bunch of different things on my own I gave up in mid  August which is when they went gold with it. Full disclosure: I do have the game installed on my laptop too and that works fine but I rarely use my Laptop at home (where I have a guaranteed internet connection) and when I do go out with it I usually have other things I need doing instead. Sol Forge seems like a fairly basic game but I can't really say whether I like it or not since I've never played a person with it, only the bots which are predictably bad. My "no" is with the caveat that is you like simpler CCGs and don't want to really think too much during play then Sol Forge might fit your bill. But Caveat Emptor. There are no refunds (if you buy packs and then find it suddenly doesn't work for some reason) and no one will care if it doesn't work for you.My initial reason for getting Early Access had less to do with what I knew about the game (not a lot) and more to do with who was making it. Brian Kibler, Justin Gary and crew have been involved with CCGs for a very long time indeed and have some amazing credentials between them. I've never gotten a chance to play their other big game Ascension but as I understand it, it is quite elegant and powerfully fun. Sadly Sol Forge didn't strike me that way though it has its charms. The 5 factions are I assume just the beginning of the diversity as I am sure many sets will be produced eventually. I hope someday I have something more positive to say about the game.

content:
Posted: April 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								The Good: Solid card game with a good balance between strategy and fun. Many possible deck variations choosing from 4 different card pools. Nice short games (usually). Very generous with booster pack unlocks and in-game currency. Syncs with mobile versions of the game. Nice level-up mechanic that introduces addition strategy into the very act of playing the cards. Simple, easy to read interface. Great artwork and some of the cards have a neat evolution of appearance as the cards level up. Recent updates slowly add a new expansion set of cards. The Bad: A bit simple if you're a veteran of Magic: the Gathering. Hard to see what the opponent plays sometimes because it flashes by too quickly (although you can go back to the log to look). Only 4 schools/houses of spells. Not as well polished as Hearthstone which has nice spell animations and creature sounds and highlights spells and effects as they happen. Deck construction is a little messy the way the cards are displayed although the filters do help. Slightly clunky menus and interface in general.Overall: Great card game that is worth spending your time in. Great on the go, especially if you link the game to a mobile device. Simpler than Magic but still fun. Lacks the polish and oomph of Hearthstone's sound and animation but far more generous with free card/booster unlocks and in-game currency. That's honestly the main thing that really keeps me hooked to logging in daily. Otherwise, I'd probaly spend more time grinding Blizzard's game which requires a lot more grinding to unlock cards unless you want to spend cash. Ultimately, I am divided between both online CCGs and find them both equally enjoyable in different ways.

								 Wanna know how much worth it it is, compared to MTG? BIG TIME. Mostly because it does what MTG doesn't:1. The gameplay is more simplified.2. There ARE no infinite combos; that's because the game is STRICTLY strategy based, where you can only use two cards per turn!3. It's FREE TO PLAY! And no terrible freemium offers, either!4. This is a MUST, for anyone who wants a simplified alternative, to MTG.(P.S.; to those who don't know what "MTG" stands for, it stands for "Magic: the Gathering"!)

content:
Posted: November 23, 2015
Early Access Review
								A Note before this begins: This is my very first Steam Review. Coupled with the fact I'm rather poor at giving feedback, I apologize in advance for this review's probably not being up to par with most peoples'. I'll be returning to this review to alter and add onto it, as I am oft wont to do; and just as well, as a read of what is below will demonstrate that in a single session, I cannot compose anything even remotely approaching the standards of an acceptably comprehensive body.Disclaimer: This review is based wholly upon my own experience and opinion of the game. I do not claim to speak for anyone else, nor presume to, nor do I believe my opinion to be factual, nor any closer to objective truth than anyone else's. I entrust the reader to understand this applies to the whole of the review, including sentences wherein clauses that disclaim this are absent.___Like more than a few 90's kids, I definitely met the Battle Card Genre growing up. The Pokemon Trading Card Game; Yu-Gi-Oh; Digimon; and many more battle card games caught the interest of so many others in my age group (and beyond, even!). All of these were very popular, I took a look at all of them- and I never took to any of them. The Battle Card game genre was simply not for me, and still largely hasn't been.Even so, there's been something interesting about the genre and many of its products in my opinion, even from a distance. So I've spent time of late looking for one that I might be able to enjoy. Countless ones, I've read of, seen numerous demonstrations for, and found myself uninterested in, just like old times.Then, the two nights preceding the one wherein I write this review, I gave it another try. I found two very interesting prospective games. One, is Infinity Wars. It looks amazing, and I'd love to try it, but it commands space my potato cannot provide.The other is SolForge.Well, I installed it last night, started playing today, and if my impressions must be expressed in a single sentence, let it be this: I, someone who has never played a battle card game before, like, perhaps even am finding love for, this game.I must start with the gameplay itself. As most reading this probably know, the game's playing area consists of ten spaces in a five-by-two arrangement. One strip of five is used by each of the two players; each space can be occupied by a card. In my opinion, this provides enough room for strategy to truly matter, while at the same time not intimidating a player as the presentation of a vast field can sometimes do. This having been said, a somewhat claustrophobic feeling often sets in when placing a card, adding a feeling of tension that can throw a player off-focus- which, in my opinion, is very satisfying to focus through the fog of.Cards come in two variants: Creature and Spell. Creature cards have two statistics, Attack Power and Health, and most of them have a special ability (and/or multiple ones, in the case of some cards) There are four main factions, each with its own pool of cards. Once again, simplicity that provides room for complexity.There are many other rules of the game that I'd love to individually praise, but I realize this is dragging on. I'll probably return to add onto the list and give my critique of each element of the gameplay that I can in kind on one of the aforementioned review edits I'm bound to do. Until then, let us move on.The instilling of a feeling of tension mentioned in the paragraph about the playing field is just as well, as the cards in this game represent troops fighting and dying within the game's fictional universe. That brings me to what I'd like to talk about next: The appeal thereof.In my opinion, the creators of this game have done a splendid job of making the lore and universe of this game very interesting. Each of the four main factions has its own unique characters, locations, and (most notably in my mind) culture and elements there-comprising, including their own unique ideals, established government, and general mindset toward life, the world, and even to each other. If you are interested, I'd advise to go to the developers' official website for the game and read their lore section. The descriptions there are highly descriptive, and will give you an idea of the world one is stepping into. There are no direct third-person descriptions of such nature in the game itself, ironically, nor any link to the official website- something I have mixed feelings about.Even though direct explanations are not provided in the game itself, the game's universe does shine through- and how! In the campaign modes, the "Info" bubbles often relay colorful descriptions of the setting in which your avatar (you?) find(s) her/him/yourself, and/or interactions with the culture of the given faction that one will be facing off against.Additionally, and in my opinion most noticeably, the images on the cards themselves associated with each faction give insight into the creatures, constructs, and, in particular, the people and, again, culture of that faction. In my eyes and mind, the characters themselves, their attire, their stances and activities, anything they might be holding, the setting each one is portrayed in, even the variations between the images for the different variations in each card, each and all seem to portray living beings with stories to tell, things to show, and a culture/environment/etc. to go back to after the dust of battle has settled. I find myself imagining what they do in peace-time, and in different situations, what a day in each one's life is like. Numerous specific examples swarm my mind, which I've been tripping over myself on my keyboard trying to type as examples, before finally deciding to leave it at this and hope it is moderately acceptable in the way of portraying my opinion of the developers' success. As I look at this paragraph, I am aghast at the degree to which I have utterly failed to express my true wonderment, and opinion of the importance that each card's image plays in picturing the fictional universe. Perhaps I'll come back and go into further detail.On this note, the artistry of the images themselves is, in my opinion, utterly breathtaking. Even outside of what it does in communicating each character's place in the fictional universe and as an extension thereof, there is much, in my opinion, to be admired. The lighting, shading, and coloration of each item and creature make each one feasible to visualize existing and moving in real, three-dimensional space, even with the obvious fantastical flair of the objects and creatures themselves.There are other elements of this game that are meritorious of praise. I also fully intend to go back and add onto, edit, and otherwise adjust each and every paragraph to be more descriptive, and adhere more loyally to the purpose of describing the experience that I have with this game. Additionally, there are numerous elements of the game I've not yet experienced, such any of the campaign missions beyond the first four, or the Multiplayer mode.From one who never liked battle card games before, and is still wary of them for the most part, this game receives a hearty recommendation. If you're interested in battle card games, and/or otherwise turn-based strategy, and you have five-hundred Megabytes to spare on your hard drive, I would recommend giving this game a try. Though there are card packs for sale (none of which I've yet patronized), the game itself is free of monetary cost. Worst case scenario, uninstall if you don't like, no less the wealthy for having tried it.(Review created/posed 11/23/2015, 10:17 PM, GMT-6. First edited at 1:16 PM, 12/3/2015, GMT -6)

								Its an alright game. If you dont mind the campaign cheating against you. Online vs other players is ok. But challenging the PC and it will just cheat you. Imagine playing an opponent and he gets to heal completely right before he dies, or an opponent who gets to do 3 damage to everything you play right off the bat. Or am opponent that kills your cards just for successfully attacking them lol.  Now if we got those powers too it wouldnt be so bad, but to just give the PC opponent an unfair advantage is just plain dumb. I mean, its the only way to unlock more cards (unless you wanna pay) and they have to cheat to keep  ya from winning.....MTG had a similar concept where you could use a BIG card that gave you an advantage during the game, but at least your opponent also got to chose one. This is just 1 sided....

content:
Posted: January 16
Product received for free
												Bleh, Enjoyed the game while it lasted.... was great that you could get ALL of the content with out real money, if you played long enough...  And as others have stated, they development team did shoot themselves in the foot as time went on with the UI and the continual changes of the tournament brackets and rewards.  The last two continually made it progressively harder to  keep getting awesome rewards.  All in all, was a fun game that was easy to play, simple rules, no "permission plays" (other players could not interrupt your own plays, only on board cards and a few auto triggered cards limited your plays), and I actually talked to devs a few times via steam chat!  Solid cudos points for that in my book!

Early Access Review
								A Free-To-Play Card game... These seem to be a dime a dozen as of lately here on Steam but there is nothing wrong with that. This one is very straight forward. You get five spaces to place cards and only two types of cards- Creatures and Spells which alter the attack or health of the Creatures. The matches can be really quick or can last a good ten minutes depending on the cards you use. Online is very good and out of the 2 hours I have played, I only had one connection failure that may have had to do with my internet connection as opposed to the game's server.If you like Magic The Gathering or Pokemon cards or the old school version of Yu Gi Oh, I suggest playing this.

content:
Posted: November 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								The closest game I can equate SolForge to is chess.  Chess with cards, which means the chess pieces are not always the same, nor does your opponent have the same pieces as you posess. So, why do I equate it with chess. I equate it with chess as it is the only game, I came over to Steam from playing SolForge on my iPhone, I have played on my phone that allows me to think. To really use my brain. The process of using my losses and wins, by utilizing the knowledge and wisdom of other players on the various forums, and building on experience I gain by playing everyday. Rewards me with a  deep satisfaction, and a sense of enhancing my brain as I received over the years of learning and playing chess. I do not know how to recommend to someone well or  high enough to play SolForge. Nor how to thank all those involved in creating and continually improving this wonderful game. Particularly in comparision to the benefits I receive  by playing this game not to mention my  appreciation to all involved with SolForge for their generosity in the countless gifts the give to help their players, which to me is so very kind of them, and when combined with the benefits I stated earlier makes this game, to me, an absolute joy and a priceless gem.Sincerely,Strangebear

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								I haven't spent a single cent on this game but I find myself playing it more than any other game on Steam or my android.  The great thing about Solforge is that all you have to do is login once a day and/or win a game and you get free cards and Silver.  The Silver you win can even be used to purchase additional booster packs with more cards!  After a week or two of playing the computer, I had a decent enough collection to build my own decks and play against others online.  If you download the android version, it syncs with your PC account so you can take your collection with you to the toilet.The game isn't perfect.  I think the interface could be improved especially in deck building mode.  This is more of an issue with the mobile version of Solforge as opposed to the PC version.  There are still some balance issues to work out with individual cards but that's what patches are for.  Some players will let the timer run out on their turn if they are losing and force you to sit there for 10 minutes because they refuse to concede.  This is more of an issue with the community rather than the game but it's the only time I have ever been frustrated with Solforge.  If you are a fan of Magic: The Gathering or Adventure Time's Card Wars, you will enjoy Solforge.  It's easy to learn but difficult to master.

content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								sadly, this is ultimately just another P2W game in a world of P2W games. i played this right when it came out. i was one of the earliest fans of the game, and played avidly every day. the game was tremendous, rewards were just right too. i was on the forums defending the game against those who called it p2w. how dare they!then the game started to descend into p2w. i'm not a "gamer" per say, so i don't devote a lot of my day to gaming. what time i have i tend to use judiciously, only on games i deem worthy. solforge lost my interest. recently, i decided to come back to it, to see how it had improved. sadly, the game has now become so p2w that i need to write a review to warn others to stay away.point-by-point:PRO:great depth and strategyfun deck buildingmatches can be tense and thrillinggetting new cards and rewards is a blastCON:new super-powerful legendaries are crazy powerful and game breaking vs players (you) who do not have them. you will very rarely acquire a card this good thru the free rewards, and even if you do the big spenders will stack their deck with multiples. Example: i played a game vs a guy who summoned 3-4 creatures the whole game. his legendaries were far more powerful than anything i could summon, and he then used his legendary spells to continuously augment them. the game was horribly painful for me. timer: this has been mentioned again and again, but even as i write my review this is happening. you have a thrilling game. your enemy is at 6 hp and you are at 7, but your position is finally overpowering & he is going to lose in 1 or 2 turns after you overwhelm his defences. well guess what, the game has a 20 minute timer per player and sore losing is always an option, right? so if he has 15 minutes left be prepared for a 15 minute wait. Actually, scratch that. what he will probably do, like many others, is wait 14 minutes. by then he is hoping you are doing something else, and he will make a move. if you are doing something else and not paying attention, now YOUR timer will run out, and YOU lose.haha so fun. trolling BUILT INTO the game for losers to exploit how great.draft play: well this WOULD be fun, but honestly is just kind of makes the whole game silly. it's a CCG, and now instead of being a CCG it's just a card game. i guess if this is the only mode you will ever play i can honestly recommend this game.A NOTE: dont assume most players you meet will be playing with just the free cards. people spend enormous amounts of money on iaps, and this game is no different. odds are you will get crushed, ESPECIALLY if you are a new player entering the playerbase at this time.the saddest part of all this is that it's easily fixable by introducing a matchmaking mechanic similar to the one found in banner saga. every card can be given a value based on it's rarity: then players can be matched up to people whose decks "total rarity" is similar to your decks. that would make things pretty fair, as it would all be up to skill at that point. the devs will NEVER do this. do you know why? they want you to get crushed. they want your soul to get crushed. because then you will spend money.so just go away now.

content:
Posted: May 3, 2015
Early Access Review
								By today's standards SolForge is not a good game.  You can not directly choose which of your characters attacks the enemy characters nor can you directly choose which of your characters blocks the enemy characters.  You just lay out your creatures and hit the 'battle' button.  Very old-school mechanic which have been repeated by games like Battlegrounds with almost no success.  My review is based on about an hour of gameplay so that must be considered.  However, I don't see much value in this game when other free-to-play games are much better.  Games like Hearthstone, Infinity Wars, and Might and Magic: Duel of Champions make SolForge feel like a college project instead of a full-fledged game.I liked the use of sound effects and graphics during combat...it's about the only appealing thing I found in this game.4/10 - I'll come back in a year and check it out again

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								Solforge is one of the more unique online collectable card games. A feature which really sets it aside, is that once a card is cast, it levels to the next tier, adding new abilities and stronger stats the next time it is drawn. It still has a large amount of depth for something that seems quite streamlined at first.The gameplay is somewhat simpler than more in depth games such as magic the gathering, and luck can have somewhat more of an influence on occasion. This can lead to some epic comebacks and to some fights where you just didn't quite get what you needed. Most of the time, fortunately, your own card decisions and anticipations of the other players moves and deck composition are still strong enough determining factors for victory ( although not all would agree). This is assuming the other player has a similar skill level and deck level to your own,which is not guaranteed with every match just yet, hopefully a ranking system will be fully implemented.Is it fun and worth grinding through and throwing a few quid at ( I've spent £3.50) ? It was for me, try it and make a decision. I wouldnt recommend spending much more than 5-10 quid ot get you going, if anything. You can grind through and learn, learning from other players in the community and your wins/losses.The game has a really quality feature of weekly tournaments, which you can enter with event tickets ( fairly easy to obtain for free). There are constructed tournaments ( pre made decks - stay away until you have some stronger decks made) and draft competitions, where you make a deck from the cards given out. In the non-casual draft, you can actually keep all the cards you pick  in addition to some you win. I can't stress enough the importance of this! you get to keep some horoic and rare cards that are essential to the cores of certain deck builds. It will dramatically increase your card and deck arsenal whilst you enjoy some more evenly matched draft based games. You will have some poor draft tounaments some times, picking the wrong card combos. It's not always ideal, but its quite consistent with choices offered.Yes, some players who are silly enough or rich enough do pay for cards and get there quicker (although high pricing of this approach seems to discourage it, imo). But this is the case with many free to play games. The important thing is you can get there spending next to nothing in my opinion anyway, and I personally found the journey to be a fulfilling one, full of ups and downs.You can also play on your phone or tablet, although lag can be an issue.If hearthstone didn't grip you, Solforge might. If you loved hearthstone, I'm sure you will enjoy solforge as well.

content:
Posted: November 28, 2016
												Earlier this year, Stone Blade Entertainment rolled out a new client for this game, and it was pretty unstable during the launch period. This upset a lot of people and led to a lot of negative reviews on here, which I don't think is particularly fair considering most online games have rocky launches. While the new client does have some annoying bugs, it is way more stable than the previous version, so take those comparisons with a grain of salt.Gameplay wise this game is like a combination of dominion and MTG. I love the core gameplay, although I don't always agree with their balancing decisions. Generally cards have less RNG than card games like duelyst or hearstone, although it still is used occasionally. The monitization model is one of the most ethical I have seen, compared to other online tcg's solforge practically hands out cards.  It's very possible to build a solid collection without spending any money, although it's definately faster if you are willing to spend some cash.The meta is pretty healthy with a lot of variety amongst the tier one decks, and drafting is extremely fun and accesible for new players. If you like TCGs but don't like the monetization model of something like hearthstone, this is a solid alternative and is imo the best online tcg availible.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: March 7, 2016
Early Access Review
								sadly, this is ultimately just another P2W game in a world of P2W games. i played this right when it came out. i was one of the earliest fans of the game, and played avidly every day. the game was tremendous, rewards were just right too. i was on the forums defending the game against those who called it p2w. how dare they!then the game started to descend into p2w. i'm not a "gamer" per say, so i don't devote a lot of my day to gaming. what time i have i tend to use judiciously, only on games i deem worthy. solforge lost my interest. recently, i decided to come back to it, to see how it had improved. sadly, the game has now become so p2w that i need to write a review to warn others to stay away.point-by-point:PRO:great depth and strategyfun deck buildingmatches can be tense and thrillinggetting new cards and rewards is a blastCON:new super-powerful legendaries are crazy powerful and game breaking vs players (you) who do not have them. you will very rarely acquire a card this good thru the free rewards, and even if you do the big spenders will stack their deck with multiples. Example: i played a game vs a guy who summoned 3-4 creatures the whole game. his legendaries were far more powerful than anything i could summon, and he then used his legendary spells to continuously augment them. the game was horribly painful for me. timer: this has been mentioned again and again, but even as i write my review this is happening. you have a thrilling game. your enemy is at 6 hp and you are at 7, but your position is finally overpowering & he is going to lose in 1 or 2 turns after you overwhelm his defences. well guess what, the game has a 20 minute timer per player and sore losing is always an option, right? so if he has 15 minutes left be prepared for a 15 minute wait. Actually, scratch that. what he will probably do, like many others, is wait 14 minutes. by then he is hoping you are doing something else, and he will make a move. if you are doing something else and not paying attention, now YOUR timer will run out, and YOU lose.haha so fun. trolling BUILT INTO the game for losers to exploit how great.draft play: well this WOULD be fun, but honestly is just kind of makes the whole game silly. it's a CCG, and now instead of being a CCG it's just a card game. i guess if this is the only mode you will ever play i can honestly recommend this game.A NOTE: dont assume most players you meet will be playing with just the free cards. people spend enormous amounts of money on iaps, and this game is no different. odds are you will get crushed, ESPECIALLY if you are a new player entering the playerbase at this time.the saddest part of all this is that it's easily fixable by introducing a matchmaking mechanic similar to the one found in banner saga. every card can be given a value based on it's rarity: then players can be matched up to people whose decks "total rarity" is similar to your decks. that would make things pretty fair, as it would all be up to skill at that point. the devs will NEVER do this. do you know why? they want you to get crushed. they want your soul to get crushed. because then you will spend money.so just go away now.

number of helpful: 1 of 3 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: January 2, 2015
Early Access Review
								I've only just started playing, and while my TCG exposure has only been a few matches of Magic, and 10 hours of Hearthstone, I have to say that this is a super fun one. The card art is great for the most part. Each creature card has 3 levels, and the card art changes as the card gets stronger mid game. A really unique mechanic and it's fun to have the game evolve to a stronger and stronger level as time goes on. There's no mana in the game, so you can play any two cards in your hand during you turn, with the hand being entirely rerolled each turning, giving weight to the decision of which cards to play. This is because each time you play a card, you level it up, so the next time you draw the card, it'll be one level higher, often unlocking new abilities.The game's not flawless though, there's not nearly the same amount of polish as a game like Hearthstone, and there's no visible ranking, although the game has a hidden ELO system, and there's a new UI incoming. There's a great card selection, easily over 400 cards, if my math is right. A bunch of different types of spells and creatures, although there is some overlap between them. The best part about the game is that it basically throws currency at you, so you're able to buy a♥♥♥♥♥♥ton of basic cards. You get about 2000 to log in each day, and the most common of the cards can be bought for 150. I respect that, and I'm alright with there being rarer cards worth up to 34k. The game's free to play, they need to make money somehow.Overall, I heartily recommend the game.

								awesome collectible card gamePRO:* it's free* crossplay on your mobile devices (tablets/smartphones)* allows you to complete your daily quests against the A.I.* generous quest rewards (you can get 2 packs/day and some coins by playing a few quick A.I. matches)* great card art* the 4 factions/colors feel very distinct* fantastic CCG mechanics (imagine Hearthstone with lanes and Pokemon-style evolutions)* easy to pick up, hard to master* the game receives regular updates* campaign mode is fun & freeCON:* the interface looks/feels better on mobile devices* online competition can be pretty hardcore for new players* the A.I. is easily exploitable (just like in Hearthstone)--> if you like CCG's you need to play this game

								I have a lot of hours accumulated on this because I leave it open a lot. Honestly, for a free card game, it's not half bad. I've definitely gotten some enjoyment from it, and you don't need to invest money into it for cards if you have some patience and play to get the cards from rewards.Pros: Easy to learn, pretty big variety of cards and not pay to win like Hearthstone.Cons: Could just be me but this game does feel more influenced by RNG compared to a game like Hearthstone, which is something I don't like. number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pros- Very strategic at times (wide decision trees for those who like to mull it over)- Very intuitive at times (narrowing those decision trees, on the surface, can seem quick and easy)- Brewing (executing that master plan with your quirky combos is excellent)- Drafting (picking and pairing happens asynchronously, no advantage for whales)- Free currency (daily rewards in order to collect currency and cards are not tedious or overbearing)Cons- Interface for all devices is slow (you will think sometimes that you are disconnected from the world, but you're not)- Interface for all devices is bugged (which means learning how to play the game well involves a period of trial and error regarding some game input/output, e.g., time clocks, cancelling card effects)- Some card rules and interactions are not made clear (and after researching this a bit, it appears to be more of an issue of lazy programming than it is an issue of making the game newbie-friendly)- Features which have been promised for a while (single-player campaign) have been put on the backburner in favor of some which weren't ever really neededThis game is always changing, but this list of pros and cons has remained the same since I started playing the first Steam-released version.

content:

Early Access Review
								I've been playing TCGs for years now, mostly sticking to Magic with a bit of Hearthstone, so when I heard about SolForge I just had to download it.It's a bit different to your average card game in the fact that there's specific lanes you can place your creatures into for attacks, similar to Scrolls, but it works. It's complicated and unfamiliar at first, and seems quite daunting, but the in-game help system is a breeze to use and explains everything explicitly and clearly, without sounding like a complicated rule book. It's a fun twist on the classic genre.A bit un-user-friendly and buggy at times, but I'm sure the devs will make it better for final release.If you like Magic or Hearthstone, give this baby a go. You'll love it.Also, the art is GAWJUS!!! Jus' sayin'7/10 Fun, but UI could be better.

								Absolutely love this game. Unluck any other Online TCG games I've played, you can actually earn 3/4 of the daily rewards just by playing against computers! 								Ok I am changing my review today.  The game is not at the level of smart one would have hoped for it to be.  Really, with the game as it stands, it is a troll game once you start to get good cards.  The only skil it seems to foster is in draft games: you need to be a good shopper and pick the best produce to fit in in your basket - then pretty much let the game run itself on auto pilot when you play.  Very rarely do you get to use your brain in this game, because:1) card shuffle randomness2) there is no deck for every situation3) does your battle of the bulge beat your opponents blitz?4) rarely does using multiple spells combat simply very strong creature cards- so being cute, fancy or inspired doesn't cut it in most matches against nerd players.Finally, there are a ton of FTP card games out there that have a much more involved system than this one.  Solforge was simply the dumbest easiest one I found and played it because I never played Pokemon or Yugi-oh and was wondering if I missed out on anything.  Apprently, not.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: April 4
												This is my favorit CCG.  Easy to pick up, but the winning curve is steep.  Nothing else like it out there with leveling cards.  Great depth in card combo and mixing factions.  It makes other CCG's seem juvenile... and its FREE!  If you have a sensitive ego, you will be crushed - You WILL lose ALOT!  The campaign will take you through various playing styles, and how the factions fair.  If you get discouraged, maybe knowing that I lost over 20 - 30 times before finding a suitable deck to beat some of the mid - late levels.  Daily quests, draft, and packs are given quite generously.  You can easily rack up 10+ packs in a couple days.  Drafts are awesome since you keep the cards (to a point).  The battle mechanics are what makes this game - engaging, evolving, and dynamic.

number of helpful: 0 of 1 people (0%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								I disagree that this game is pay to win, i have never paid for anything within this game and even after not playing for half a year and returning, I find that my old decks still hold up very well vs swarms of new cards I had never seen before including the ones that can go up to level 4. *edit* After checking the shop for the first time in ages I've noticed they have bumped the price of free in game currency card packs by a ridiculous amount, which I suppose could make the game quite a bit more grindy when you are starting out, they have bumped the price from 900 silver to 5k which is ridiculous considering you normally get about 4-6k silver from your 3 wins bonus per day. This is clearly an attempt to make people purchase boosters with real money which is a shame. That being said, what I like about this game is how the combat works, everything gets a lane and everything is required to attack, there is no saving a monster on the field for later nor in your hand as it gets refreshed every turn. This also prevents people from being total asses and just destroying all your monsters and leaving you alive forever like in other CCGs. When you use a card it levels up into the next tier and becomes unusuable until  you yourself level up, as the cards go through levels they get stat boosts and ability boosts, some of them even gain abilities they don't start with.This IS a game you will have to play daily  if you want to have a decent deck though, you need 3 wins per day in order to get all the free rewards which include silver(free currency that can be used to buy basic boosters) and a random item that can be  an event ticket, a card(which is usually terrible and the worst reward) or a booster pack of any tier(I think I received 3 premium packs in the first month of playing). After about the first 2-3 weeks you should be able to assemble a decent deck and after that it's all a matter of tweaking. you are allowed to use cards from 2 out of the 4 factions in your deck which also creates some interesting combos.Legendaries are well...legendaries, they either fall into the massive stats and terrible abilities type or the very  very squishy but amazing ability  type. Legendaries tend to start off way weaker at the first level but become better at endgame, what this means is that if you can put the pressure onto your enemy and  force them to put up normal monsters in order to defend, do it. This will cripple their lategame and potentially make the difference on whether you win or not.Spells are also a major part of the game, there are no traps or secrets just regular spells. They can be buffs like armor, damage,  heals, special abilities like moving on the board or damage that goes through defending monsters etc. Or debuffs and damage: straight up nukes, poisons, debuffing of hp and attack(debuffing hp to negative CAN be used as a killing technique and has the benefit of going directly thorugh armor at the cost of usually doing way less damage than a nuke does).It is a different system to get used to but once you do I find it is quite fun, matches are quite quick and you can play multiple at the same time, plus they just got android support so you can officially play it on just about any tablet or phone now. As long as you long in once a day and do your 3 wins (you can even play against bots if you're lazy since they're very easy) you will have very nice cards. The only cards you cannot get for free are the alternate arts*(essentially shiny cards) they release once a week
