content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								ORIGINALLY NOT EARLY ACCESS, SolForge is a decent free to play card game with some of the easiest mechanics of any card game I've ever played. Choose cards from four factions (nature, fire, death, and robots), make a 30 card deck, and fight the computer or an online opponent. You get two actions per turn (except for the first turn, when the player can only play one card), and as you play you gain levels in order to play higher-level cards. Any cards you don't play don't gain levels, and any cards you don't use get discarded. Several cards synergize for higher levels of strategy, but overall this is a simple game anyone can play. If you don't mind being limited to only two actions per turn, that is.

content:
Posted: December 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pros- Very strategic at times (wide decision trees for those who like to mull it over)- Very intuitive at times (narrowing those decision trees, on the surface, can seem quick and easy)- Brewing (executing that master plan with your quirky combos is excellent)- Drafting (picking and pairing happens asynchronously, no advantage for whales)- Free currency (daily rewards in order to collect currency and cards are not tedious or overbearing)Cons- Interface for all devices is slow (you will think sometimes that you are disconnected from the world, but you're not)- Interface for all devices is bugged (which means learning how to play the game well involves a period of trial and error regarding some game input/output, e.g., time clocks, cancelling card effects)- Some card rules and interactions are not made clear (and after researching this a bit, it appears to be more of an issue of lazy programming than it is an issue of making the game newbie-friendly)- Features which have been promised for a while (single-player campaign) have been put on the backburner in favor of some which weren't ever really neededThis game is always changing, but this list of pros and cons has remained the same since I started playing the first Steam-released version.

The "Consistent" abilities were designed to allieviate this issue, but seems to be tied to useless cards.

number of helpful: 3 of 8 people (38%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 22, 2016
												I can see why this game has mixed reviews.I'm a new player. Wasn't involved in the Kickstarter. Didn't play the earlier version. I joined in August 2016 knowing NOTHING about the game ahead of time.At first, it's super fun and addicting. Going through the campaign is SO EASY ... until you get to the final one, and then it's ABRUPTLY, IMPOSSIBLY HARD. Even after improving my decks, getting more powerful cards, learning multiple strategies in the game... I STILL can't beat that final campaign challenge. Ugh. No real transition between effortlessly easy to suddenly impossibly hard.And that's just playing against the computer.Try playing against real human players? Heh. I can't tell a difference between ranked or unranked matches. Either way, once in a blue moon, I face an opponent who's cards and skills are relatively comparable to mine. THE REST OF THE TIME, I'm facing players with tons of "legendary" rare cards that are EXTREMELY over-powered and broken, especially when used in the right combination with other legendary cards... Countless times I haven't even gotten a chance to damage my opponent once before they obliterate me. It's beyond frustrating.Slowly, I'm acquiring more powerful and useful cards. But the only way I seem to get ahead (without spending lots of money) is to play a bunch of PvP matches and HOPE that some internet error makes it so they never actually connect with or play against me... the match starts, but they never do any actions, and eventually it times out and counts it as a win for me! Woohoo! After 3 wins, I get a random reward: usually a draft ticket or booster deck. After 6 wins, the same again. And you get a small bonus (usually just silver coins, which are pretty much useless) just for loggging in daily.Draft tickets (it takes 4 of them) allow you to enter into tournaments. If you pick the draft one (not a pre-built deck one), you get to acquire some uncommon and rare cards, and keep them after the tournament. That's the ONLY way I've managed to build up even half of a decent deck after several weeks of playing almost daily.If it's such a bad game, why do I keep playing it?I think it's Flappy Bird Syndrome. It's FRUSTRATINGLY hard. But hey, the artwork is beautiful and it's kind of like playing Magic the Gathering... I don't play this game to have fun. I play it because it's nearly impossible to win (without dumping a ton of money on a deck full of legendary cards) and for some reason that hopeless challenge keeps pulling me back... for now. I never get very far, but once in a while I'll earn a win, and that victory feels f--ing amazing!

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: July 8, 2016
Early Access Review
								Alright, honestly I'm tired of people giving the new client or the new reward system crap and saying you need hundreds of Legendaries to play the game. For the New Client: Yes it has bugs, it's a brand new client and a complete overhaul of the GUI, OF COURSE IT HAS BUGS, and SBE is working on fixing them, however they can't do a bunch of small hotfixes because they're working on three platforms, one of which makes updates really difficult, so grouping a bunch of fixes is easier to do for the devs. For the New Reward system, yes it makes you play against other players which can be a little daunting, but realistically even just getting the ticket for 3 games played is easy as pie and after a week or two of playing and getting cards through draft and what not even the 3 wins isn't that hard. The new reward system drastically increases the ability to get new cards by allowing players to draft every other day. I have played since alpha and can say with certainty that this reward system is sooooo much better than the old stuff. For all the people who think you need a crapton of legendaries to play online: Having a deck that is one of the top teir meta decks is all well and good, but yes it is very hard to acquire in a FTP account, it isn't impossible however, AND more importantly you don't need a top teir deck to be able to play and get wins, hell you dont even necessarily need Legendaries beyond the great ones you can get through campaign, I have a Spirit Wanderer deck, it runs 1 legendary: Varna (who you can get in campaign), and 4 heroics: 2 relentless wanderers and 2 rutheless wanderers, and that deck has yet to lose to MonoNekruim hate (A strong deck running a lot of legendaries), Nekruim-anything Fiend (Dont even get me started on this deck), and Stall/Level Chrogias/Iron Maiden (another one of those obnoxious decks that you see a lot of)I have a Darkforged UT deck, that beats most other decks i've played it against, including a titanium 1 Ignir decklist. How many legendaries does that deck have? Oh... right, it doesn't, I built it for a nonlegendary tournament a couple of my friends where trying to do. Anyways, sorry for the rant I'm just tired of people being super salty about not being able to build "top Tier" netdecks, and the client update. TLDR: the game isn't bad, it's quite fun honestly, you don't need a ton of legendaries to make a good deck (you just need to really look at the cards and find synergy) and the new reward system is leagues better for new players than it was in the "good ol days" If nothing else give the game a shot, find a couple friends who are okay with building silly decks and troll around, you might find something that beats the meta ;) and you know what if you hate it go ahead and uninstall, that's fine too, but don't pass the game by just because a bunch of people are being salty.

								This game is in Early Access so I would assume some things are going to be changed but IMO there is too much that needs to be changed for this game to be reasonable to purchase.  This game as been in Early Access for 3 years according to their "Soon to Launch" announcment.  Yet some of the basic tutorial missions are frustratingly unbeatable, the interface is clunkly with pop-ups that disapear before you can read them, I've found myself stuck in load screens that wont end.They self admit there are a lot of F2P card games out there, I would suggest looking at those instead of this.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 15, 2016
Early Access Review
								Solforge is a great card game which is different to most of the other games out there.   Most CCG's follow a mana bar pattern where you start off small playing critters, then as your mana increases you play bigger controlling cards, ultimately leading up to your big hitter cards which cost the most mana.     I get bored of this format of playing critters->controlling cards->big hitters.     In Solforge the cards you play in the opening rounds could be the most important plays of the game.SBE as a company have listened to their player base and have made numerous requested changes to the new client.  In particular you can now earn rewards against the AI again.   This means that casual players, like me, have a method of daily progression.

number of helpful: 2 of 6 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: September 25, 2016
												TLDR I am a rabid fan who hasn't dropped a dime on this game in 2.5 years but have a massive collection, play competitively, adore draft, and just earned $40 of in-game gold in competition this past weekend.  I am not the only one.Let's be frank, I've sunk a lot fo hours into this game--in fact, I play 2-3 hrs daily on my Android phone, so it's very likely my total horus should be around 3000 after 2.5 years of play.  I have loved this game, I have seethed at it, I have quit for months (a brutal constructed meta in SUmmer 2015) and returned.I don't understand the complaints of the new client's appearance--it is different, and people hate change, but it is easy to read and decipher what is going on and very easy to work with on PC and Android.Is it buggy--absolutely--the Discard pile can be broken by a key legend that levels cards in it, the ability to open the deck can be blocked by use of another popular legend, and if you don't know the right tricks, you can loose a brand-new deck you've just designed because the game forgot it existed.  So, player beware--it isn't a the most smooth UI in existence.  But, the core of thsi game is fantastic--I played MtG for 15 years and have never looked back.  Yes, you can get "level-screwed" but is honestly less likely to happen than in MtG or Hearthsone and you always have 2 guarenteed plays and only 5 lanes to block, so it can be survived.you're doing. As to Pay-to-win.  Two thinsg to consider: One, if a player were to drop $100 on MtG and then play in an arena where they are facing vetrans with lots of time and money invested, would we claim it's pay-to-win? Possibly, but we wouldn't assume that if that player had paid $1000 they should have been able to achieve a championship right away either.  This is a game of skill, it has a learning curve, and you are going to lose to people who have played more and have earned up to better cards.Dailies: At this point, you need to win against an online opponent to gain a booster per day--this is not simple, it was easier when you could just beat the computer for two boosters, but SBE has also made it possible to earn 2 tixkets a day just showing up 8 times (heck, you can even concede).  That means every 2 days you can pay those 4 completely free tixckets to draft 30 new cards, many of which can be new rares and heroics, and play to get new cards and silver to craft even more--and let's be clear, the single pack you earn now has a much higher-rarity drop than those of old.To cap it off, I have never spent any money on this game--I have been drafting and building and competing for almost 2.5 years, yes, but I run 3 separate accounts and am Platinum or Titanium ranked on each of them, can accrue enough silver to purchase brand new powerful cards on release, and can compete in Elite tournaments to earn valuable in-game gold for free.  I rarely play anything else; I am a rabid fan.  You'll never know if you can be one too, unless you try it for awhile.  And for all that's good, go to kaelarisladder.com and get to know the friendly and helpful side of our community

content:
Posted: September 27, 2016
												Picked this game up about a month ago, my first impressions were mixed: After having some issues figuring out how the client worked, it didn't take long to see the amount of depth the game had in turn to turn decision making being cruicial (A hand of 5 cards, 2 being able to be played every turn, the played cards level up as they go to your discard pile which eventually gets shuffeled into your deck again) gave a good first impression of the game. Blowing through the single player campaign facing unique decks which tested my deckbuliding immediatley.After the single player campaign, I decided to try assembling a deck with whatever cards I had and give it a spin in constructed. I faced decks and players way out of my league as a player starting out. My only realistic chance to get my wins for the daily quests (I later learned that if you get a friend or alternate account you can play vs them for daily quests) was that my opponents game time ran out due to the power difference between higher and lower rarity cards.I went to the draft mode since there I figured I'd at least have a chance since the collection size doesn't matter in that format, and was pleasantly suprised in the fact that whatever cards you picked up in the draft was added to your collection. With daily quests providing almost enough for a daily draft (enough if you do well in the draft) made daily drafts became an enjoyable daily dose of SolForge.+: In depth gameplay that rewards playing well. Lots of interesting card mechanics and design (Having a card in your deck adds other cards to your deck, for instance). Generous daily rewards and progression for a F2P game. (Daily draft where you keep cards). If money is spent on buying cards, an extra copy is recieved which can only be given to a friend. Chess clock-esque turn timer, making momentary disconnects Has an app for Android/iOS.-: Small playerbase which throws off matchmaking at certain times of the day. Big power difference between lower and higher rarity cards (Higher rarity cards tend to be more situational to be powerful but usually under easy to fulfil conditions). Initially confusing and buggy client that lacks some key features (chat).

content:
Posted: November 4, 2014
Early Access Review
								The game is still glitchy, it fails to run on my computer and requires a reinstall every day or so, but the fact that I am willing to do that to play this game has to say something.  Its a unique CCG where you shuffle your discard pile back into your deck every 4 turns, and rank up your cards by doing so.  It makes it so you may play a crap card early just because later it get better, which in any other CCG you would avoid putting it in your deck to begin with.

content:
Posted: October 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a Trading Card Game like no other, I assure you. Do you love playing TCG's? If so you are probably like me and have a tendancy to hate being in the middle of a duel with some low attack and defence card that you just want to cry. Well, this game will fix that for you. Why? Because using a card will not only place it back in your deck when played, but it comes back stronger as it levels up from doing so. Who wouldn't like to play that crappy 2 attk 4 def card and pulling it out again a little later now with 6 attk and 12 def and dropping it on the field next to it's weaker kin? I know I sure would. so if you want to try the new way of dueling, this game is a good haul. give it a shot.

content:
Posted: December 18, 2014
Early Access Review
								I backed this on Kickstarter and have mostly moved to playing the iPad version now that it's available, but the game is the same on both systems. It's a free to play (not pay to win) collectible card game which takes advantage of being digital to incorporate a core mechanic which would technically be possible in analog but would be clunky and annoying at best. Cards level up and go back in the deck when played, making it so that the player must consider not only what cards can do now but what they can do later in the game when making plays. The game is 100% worth a try.

								Free to play trading card game, it's easy to learn but hard to master!this game is excellent and has A LOT to offer without spending a dime, the game is really generous with awarding the players free cards and it's definitely possible to have fun and win without paying anything, though you can spend money to cards faster and guaranteed more powerful cards...the powerful cards aren't blocked off from the f2p users though it will just take them longer to aquire them, so in that sense it's not really pay to win.this is so great and I've had so much fun with it so far that I'm even tempted to spend some money on it just to support the developer...I think I'll wait a little though for them to iron out some problems:1) stability issues, especially on Ipad.2) card balancingthat said I highly recommned this game and hey it's free so it won't cost ya to try it.

number of helpful: 5 of 13 people (38%) found this review helpful1 person found this review funny
content:
Posted: July 26, 2016
												SolForge has had a tough life, but the core gameplay is still great. The recent updates and changes to the UI have prompted a wave of mostly negative reviews that exaggerate the few flaws the game has while failing to do the good points justice. Yes, some features have been changed or removed from the old UI. Yes, there are probably some more bugs present in the UI overhaul. Yes, it's a little harder to get cards without paying money. These were all necessary and inevitable changes to the game if Stone Blade has any hope of competing with the likes of Blizzard and Hearthstone. And yes, the game is more complicated and challenging than Hearthstone. But it's also more rewarding and innovative.Few if any other digital TCGs take advantage of the digital medium better than SolForge. Because of the way cards level up after you play them, your deck will constantly change over the course of a game. This means that, since you can only play two cards a turn, on every turn you will have to decide whether to level up the most powerful card in your hand or deal with your opponent's immediate threats. This dynamic deck-building on the fly would be very difficult to replicate in a traditional cardboard TCG and is SolForge's best mechanic.Despite the recent patches, accumulating a collection is still vastly easier in SolForge than it is in most TCGs. There are daily rewards for winning games, and you get to keep all the cards you pick from drafts. Booster packs can contain cards from any expansion, which means that you don't have to pick and choose depending on which cards you want. SolForge even has tournaments built in, a feature sorely lacking from Hearthstone and other games. Finally, you can share cards with your friends, making it possible to help others build their collections without spending money.I decided to write this review, because I feel this game deserves a lot more positive attention than it's been getting over the past few years. No one is writing about it, hardly anyone is making videos about it or streaming it anymore, the game is not nearly as popular as Hearthstone or Magic, and, admittedly, the devs have not done a good job of marketing the game to or communicating with their core audience. But none of that means the game has to be lost and forgotten under the weight of juvenile negative reviews or die due to a lack of players. New cards are still coming out, and the UI improvements prove that the devs still care about the game and the players.So I urge you, if you care about the future of digital TCGs at all, play SolForge. Go through the tutorials. Beat a few campaign missions. Do a draft or two. Play a few online matches. And then decide whether this game is worth your time or money. But don't let the grognards railing against the winds of change or the newbies with less than an hour of playtime cloud your judgment. Good luck, Forgeborn. You're gonna need it.

number of helpful: 3 of 9 people (33%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 11, 2016
Early Access Review
								Yes, the official launch was plagued by bugs and server-side issues.  Those have been mostly resolved.  It's to be expected from a small independent game team.  Now that that's out of the way, this is an absolutely fantastic game.  The card-leveling mechanic is innovative and adds tremendous strategic depth.  It's much better than games like Hearthstone!Like all CCG games, you can't expect to compete at the highest levels in constructed tournaments unless you spend some money.  However, draft tournaments reward pure skill.  If you want a game where you can spend nothing and 'pwn everyone' this game is not for you.  If you're willing to invest a little, you'll wonder why you ever played any other CCG!

number of helpful: 2 of 7 people (29%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: June 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								Solforge is one of the best TCG game out there. The mechanic is sharp and unique compared to other TCG I played  (Magic, HS,Duelyst etc) That is why it has gather quite a fanbase whilst it was still in beta. (it has been in beta quite a looong time. 7 sets was released in beta)Everyone was excited when Solforge finally was going to be officially launched on 31st May. Unfortunately, it was not the smoothest launch as the client was buggy and have several issues. This explain why a lot of people gotten upset and start giving negative reviews.Fortunately, SBE have addressed a lots of the issued and fixed the major bug.  The game is still not perfect yet, but it sure shows that the team developing is responding to the community call seriously.I highly reccommend everyone to try this game as it is really fun and easy to pick up. I am a FTP player and have been playing this game for a loong time. I can proudly say I have a reasonably big collection now and able compete with players who pay no problem. Hats off to the guys at SBE, it might not have been the smoothest release but they listened.   Solforge as a card game is wonderful and the client goes a long way to adding the pizzazz so it should be attractive to a wider audience now, once the obvious problems are fixed up.

number of helpful: 2 of 8 people (25%) found this review helpful
content:
Posted: August 6, 2015
Early Access Review
								It looks good but the gameplay is quite boring. Just outlast to level 3 units where you will actually duke things out. PROS1. Nice VisualsThe artwork for the cards are great.2. Easy to LearnJust play 2 cards every round if possible. Preferably choose units over spells as the stat point growth for units far exceed spells. E.g. Stone Giant 6/9 to 20/20 vs a 6 damage to 12 damage.3. Interesting AbilitiesArmour (Negates X damage on the first hit), Aggressive (Attack on Summon)4. Campaign is okayIt's still another AI battle but it's campaign is better than some other online TCGs that I've played E.g. MMDOC (Google it) CONS1. Peculiar mechanicThe idea of a default mechanic where you gain a higher level card by playing a lower level card first is quite strange. E.g. Play a Level 1 card to gain a Level 2 card of the same card.2. Repetitive cardsCard Levels go into 1, 2, 3. The next level is merely a buffed up version of the first card. E.g. Cull the Weak: Destroy any creature with 4/8/12 attack and below.3. Pay-To-WinYou get normal booster packs with Silver (in-game currency) and rare booster packs with Gold (cash currency). People who spend cash on this game will get better cards than those who don't.4. No Trading SystemCan't see anyway to trade your cards so your cards are valueless.5. Low Multiplayer CountHardly anyone playing.6. TournamentsMinimum number of event tickets to enter is 2. You need to pay cash to get these tickets. With such a low player count, I wonder why they even charge.7. BugsLot of bugs8. No unique narrativeStandard undead horde, wild animals, technology city and primordial tribe cards. This is the same story as Infinity Wars. There is nothing unique.

								If you log in before July 24th, you will recieve 1500 free gold!  Edit: Guide I wrote for New Players, please check it out: 


Feed the Children: A guide for new players on why they have it easy and how to best spend their silver. And free stuff. 
A Guide for SolForge
By: Rain Drops

			If you log in before July 24th, you will recieve 1500 free gold! Do it now! Solforge, the incredibly deep game by MtG World Champions and Richard Garfield with normal booster packs that has a 1/10 chance of legendaries...		


Original Review:The new Client is AMAZING. Everything runs so smoothly now. Any frustrations you might have with this game, give it another go, it's like a whole new game.  I love that there is a Ranked Ladder now, one that costs me nothing to participate in. And the new ticket prices for Draft (and you keep the cards) is very generous. Probably because of the double reward thing going on right now, I've been able to play one draft per day. Very nice. Managing to pull a win via Forgeguardian Omega in Draft was a delicious highlight of the new experience.I bought 10 Raiders Unchained pack to pump up my collection a bit. Love the new cards, love the new combos that I am able to piece together. That's what I like about Solforge, it's ability to consistently reinvent itself.I am still hoping for word on official No-Legendary Tournements, but that might be bad for business, which I totally understand. In draft, all Forgeborn are equal, so it's not a huge issue. A friend of my did mention that he would like to see Standard play (ie, we only play with the most recent sets). It would make things more interesting for sure, but not as accessible to everyone.The naysayers haven't played this game enough lol. Their hours are seriously lacking.

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is kinda like playing a game of yatzee. far too random in its approach. at first it looked like a game i could really enjoy. i used to play a lot of magic and i saw a lot of similar elements. the problem lies in the rank system. you play a level 1 card and it ranks up to level 2 making it more powerful so as you go a few cards that you play get more powerful and the rest stay at lower levels. then you get to rank 3 and its entirely random as to getting a full hand of nearly worthless rank 1 stuff or getting an amazing hand or even set of hands with lots of high ranking stuff. this is pretty much determines who wins. many games i felt like i could have just tossed a coin in the air to decide the winner and that doesnt make it very fun. there are better cards you can accumulate as you play that give you more of an edge but i'm not really willing to spend the time or money to get there. The draft system is also poorly imagined. you choose 30 cards for your deck but not from a pool of cards. first you pick one of 6 then one of 5 and 4 etc. frequently i wouldnt want any of the cards or just one but it wouldnt be the color that i want to play. there are 4 colors and you only get 2. there are amazing cards and i got a few on the first draft. i went 2 and 2. the second draft i played i felt like i got nothing useful and won 0 games. i recognize that sometimes you get a good hand and sometimes you dont but when it takes a week to get enough tickets to play draft i'm just not willing to waste the time needed.

content:
Posted: April 24, 2014
Early Access Review
								I will start by saying that stoneblade has produced a card game with an innovative and very interesting core mechanic. However I have exhausted a considerable amount of time into the game and have come to the conclusion that RNG 'feels' like it plays too large a hand in the game.Without going into specifics becuase people who are reading this may not have experienced the Solforge leveling system, I will say that more often than not you will lose matches and 'Feel' like you had absolutly no power. And unlike magic wereby matches you lose due to RNG are lost in the first few draws due to mana, Solforge matches are lost turn 20-30 around 10+ mintues into a match.Basically an average game of solforge has you play a card you will need leveled later and then you cross your fingers in the hope that you draw that card when you need it. But more often than not you will never see that card again and if you do see it there may be no benefit in playing it. In conclusion I don't mind losing when the game is close but the majoritiy of time you will lose because the level 1 creatures you draw will NEVER beat those level 3's your opponent keeps playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a CCG, SolForge is one of the most solidly constructed games I've played in years. It takes full advantage of the fact that it exists in virtual space to explore mechanics that would be difficult or even impossible in real space. Also, instead of banning or restricting cards, if a card becomes unbalanced in play, they won't hesistate to update it to make it more functional. However, they don't go overboard changing cards all the time, either.Like all the best games, it is fairly easy to learn, but hard to master. The basic concept is simple. You draw a hand of 5 cards, of which you can play two. There are spells and creatures. Creatures occupy one of 5 lanes. When you play a card, it levels up into another version of itself, usually a better version. How much better varies from card to card. Each turn you battle, any creature that doesn't have summoning sickness attacks the creature across from it, and if there is nothing across from it, it deals damage to the opposing player. At the end of your turn, you discard your entire hand, and draw 5 new cards. After four turns, you level up, meaning you reshuffle all your cards back into your deck, except now some of those cards are higher level. And this repeats, with your deck getting stronger as the game goes on.  There are four factions, and each of them plays differently. Decks are 30 cards, and can be made of one or two factions.From that simple structure, there is a lot of depth in the game. This game was designed by Stoneblade Entertainment, the same company that created the Ascencion deckbuilding game, with the help of Richard Garfield (creator of Magic: The Gathering). Most of them are Magic protour veterans as well. The plan, for now, seems to be to release one major set and one minor update each year. There are timed and untimed matches, as well as tournaments and drafting. The game is built to be free to play, although it is still in beta, so many things like a single-player campaign and trading cards between players are not in yet, but the game is updated fairly regularly. I definitely recommend it to anyone who is keen on strategy games or CCGs, and the free to play nature makes it easy to try out.

content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a fun game to play, and it's easy to pick up the rules and jump right in.  For a casual gamer like myself, that is a big plus.  The mechanics of "leveling" a card were new to me at first and took a little bit of time to get the hang of, but the best times I've had are figuring out good combos to play.  I played M:tG years and years ago, and at first I tried to approach SolForge like that, but I was not very successful.  I like that there are a bunch of powerful cards that you can work towards and hope that they turn up in a booster, but the ability to purchase basic booster packs using silver you win in game is a much easier way to start growing your collection.  I don't like that you can't trade cards (hopefully that get implemented in some fashion, someday down the road), and all the tournaments that I have entered were filled with very powerful decks (so I lost almost every time), but overall, this game is a great way to spend 15-30 minutes at a  time.  It's still in beta right now, and they tweak the cards when trying new game balances, but it is very polished and I have only had one or two instances where something buggy happened.  Lag is sometimes an issue too, but that might be my local connection more so than anything in the game itself.  Give SolForge a try, it is worth it.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2014
Early Access Review
								SolForge is a strange and quite unique CCG. It contains four "Factions" modeled after Technology, Nature, Life and Death. Each Faction does have it's advantages and disadvantages and you must combine two factions together to create a near-perfect card-dispensing, death-dealing deck! However SolForge is not quite as polished as other CCG's like Magic the Gathering or Hearthstone, nor is it as publicized. However It is worth playing equally as much as the other CCGs. Originality: 6Mechanics: 7Polish: 5Rating: 6/10 SolForge is an interesting game, though it lacks the polish others of it's genre have.

One of the best parts is that you can have it crash on your laptop/desktop and then immediately go to your ipad or mobile device and finish the match there. Also it means that you can play when on vacation if you can't bring a PC with you. In general I think that the game is quite amazing and despite minor bug fixes(which are totally within acceptable standards) the game is incredibly well desgined.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: November 29, 2013
Early Access Review
								For anyone that has been following me on Youtube for the past few months, you probably noticed that my focus is on digital TCGs. And SolForge has been one of the most commonly played games. Currently I am sitting at over 150 hours played (though some of that may or may not have involved accidentally leaving the game on overnight a few times) and I have played countless hands. The style of this game is what I would call a lane game (as opposed to a MTG-like or a board game like game like Faeria).First of all it is free to play. The game comes with 2 precon decks that are not in your card pool as far as I know (meaning that those 4 legendaries between the 2 decks you do not own). The prizes currently are fast to earn. Every day at midnight pacific time it resets. You get bonuses for loggin in, first win and 3rd win. The prizes are silver (free to play currency which can be used to buy play mats, the smallest booster pack, and deck slots), and randomized prizes which currently only includes cards or packs.The pacing of this game is the most enjoyable I have ever played. It is easy to play a 5-10 minute hand and just as easy to lose yourself for hours at a time. The basic gameplay is so simple that I think my cat could learn it. But the strategy does present itself if you give the game a chance. Leveling up is the resource in this game and you need to play the right cards at the right time to progress your deck properly. There is still plenty of luck... but trust me. It is less than you think there is the first time you play a hand.Plans for the future include: booster drafting and in game tournaments (coming in next patch that will be "soon").A new 20 card psuedo expansion which will be added to the current set. Save your silver to buy those new packs but don't be afraid to open any packs as old ones will not have new cards.Graphical and UI upgrades.And most importantly some form of trading and crafting. If you are not in this game for the long haul now is the time to warn potential players. The pack system is currently very frustrating. You can only get the 3 card pack for free now. I recently opened 110 of these packs and only got 2 legendary cards. Premium packs guarantee 1 legendary card. But they cost $10. And there is no way to guarantee getting the legendary you want unless they are in one of the faction starter decks. Legendary cards aren't necessarily always better. But they add depth to decks and make certain strategies work better (or make SOME viable since they do not work without specific cards). Between the fact that there is CURRENTLY no trading or in game card crafting, it can be very frustrating for new players. Or even players like me. I Kickstarted this game. I used my store credit to buy 1 of each starter pack and 145 of the middle sized booster packs. And there are still numerous legendary cards that I have 0 copies of.This game is good enough that I recommend it to anyone that loves lane based CCGs. But I want to say. If you are easily frustrated by RNG with packs. If MMDoC made you flip tables because of the lack of trading. I recommend just doing your daily bonuses against the AI, playing occasionally with your friends, and waiting until trading is implemented in game. If you have the patience to slowly build a decent card pool, then go for it!  Otherwie just remember that beta is beta and SBE is still a small company. And there are plenty of CCGs out there right now while you wait for Kibler, Justin, and the rest of the team to continue developing SolForge.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been playing this a lot since the first set was out.This is my go-to game when just chilling with my buddy who also rocks this game.Testing decks, reaching infinity (unlimited plays per turn, nice challenge, try it!)Thinking long and hard about draft choices, debating nerfs. so much fun if you enjoy strategy.Gameplay wise, this is MUCH more interesting than hearthstone, much more choices, less of a reliance on legendary's.One of my strongest decks atm (U/A spawn deck with scarabs, weirwood patr and lifeblood dryad)has only 2 (Ancestral Echoes) but they mostly make the deck slower and worse.Although it really needs a ranking system, I disagree with the p2w sentiment of some other reviews.People seem to think you can only get silver through online matches, but the best way to get cards (and to have major fun on equal footing with other players) is the draft system. The normal draft (3 event tickets, 1(+) ticket per day) nets you 30 cards to keep.this will fill out your collection fast and with the forging of excess cards, this will give you20.000+ gold for each draft. Not to mention the pretty large amount of legendary's i got from winning draft games. Too bad you can grind it all day, but this has given me a full collection everytime before a new set came out.    protip;  NEVER BUY LEGEND CHESTS Just think up a deck which needs them or netdeck the current best or something.Play for 5-10 min every day to get draft tickets > draft > sell > buy specific legendary.this is way better, not all are equal in usefulness and the chances of getting a truly good one are slim.  just get some thundersaurs or nexus aeronauts through buying.To make a long and incoherent story short;Try it, now!  just play it for 10 min of fun every day and soon you will have a decent and viable collection to toy with.tell your friends, we need more ppl playing.And stoneblade, thanks for making this awesome game, but make a ranking system. It is frustrating to go up against  twinked out meta decks if you are new.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								After playing SolForge for a while, I can say that it's no Magic: The Gathering, but it isn't bad. You get one booster pack per day just for logging in, you can earn more by winning games, and there's a single-player campaign mode that - while fairly thin - still provides a good tutorial first and a rather crushing bit of challenge later on. Will you run up against truly unfair decks online? Oh, hells yes. Will you eventually make crushingly unfair decks of your own? Sure. All in all, it's not a bad F2P - and I define that as "A F2P that you really don't have to spend money to enjoy."PROS: -Interesting gameplay.-No need to spend money, though earning cards through winning will take time.-Single-player mode intact.-Also available on AndroidCONS: -Some minor balance issues, although some of the most broken cards have been taken care of over time.-Repetitive music.-Getting your first competitive deck together will certainly take a while.Overall: 7/10. One of the better card games available on Steam.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 1, 2014
Early Access Review
								SolForge is a great CCG in the vein of Magic: The Gathering.  Unlike Magic, SolForge is much faster and easier to understand (although it still has quite a bit of strategic elements).  Also, SolForge is well adapted to digital play, compared to many CCGs that are really only "paper-based" games.  SolForge's uniqueness is in how it upgrades your cards as you play them, so your Level 1 card becomes stronger (Level 2) the next time you play it in the game.  It's quite a lot of fun to try and turn your small "squires" into giant "Knights" as you play.  The price to play is a bit high, in that you need to buy a starter and if you want more cards, you will need to acquire more boosters.  You can earn some boosters by playing each day and earning in-game currency (silver) to purchase more packs, but it is a slow process.   It is still in Beta design, but I think it's going to a great game once it's totally completed.  Both constructed and booster drafts have recently been introduced and are a LOT of fun.  Originally a dream on Kickstarter, SolForge has become a really fun and enjoyable reality!

content:
Posted: May 7, 2014
Early Access Review
								This game is kinda like playing a game of yatzee. far too random in its approach. at first it looked like a game i could really enjoy. i used to play a lot of magic and i saw a lot of similar elements. the problem lies in the rank system. you play a level 1 card and it ranks up to level 2 making it more powerful so as you go a few cards that you play get more powerful and the rest stay at lower levels. then you get to rank 3 and its entirely random as to getting a full hand of nearly worthless rank 1 stuff or getting an amazing hand or even set of hands with lots of high ranking stuff. this is pretty much determines who wins. many games i felt like i could have just tossed a coin in the air to decide the winner and that doesnt make it very fun. there are better cards you can accumulate as you play that give you more of an edge but i'm not really willing to spend the time or money to get there. The draft system is also poorly imagined. you choose 30 cards for your deck but not from a pool of cards. first you pick one of 6 then one of 5 and 4 etc. frequently i wouldnt want any of the cards or just one but it wouldnt be the color that i want to play. there are 4 colors and you only get 2. there are amazing cards and i got a few on the first draft. i went 2 and 2. the second draft i played i felt like i got nothing useful and won 0 games. i recognize that sometimes you get a good hand and sometimes you dont but when it takes a week to get enough tickets to play draft i'm just not willing to waste the time needed.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: April 20, 2014
Early Access Review
								As a CCG, SolForge is one of the most solidly constructed games I've played in years. It takes full advantage of the fact that it exists in virtual space to explore mechanics that would be difficult or even impossible in real space. Also, instead of banning or restricting cards, if a card becomes unbalanced in play, they won't hesistate to update it to make it more functional. However, they don't go overboard changing cards all the time, either.Like all the best games, it is fairly easy to learn, but hard to master. The basic concept is simple. You draw a hand of 5 cards, of which you can play two. There are spells and creatures. Creatures occupy one of 5 lanes. When you play a card, it levels up into another version of itself, usually a better version. How much better varies from card to card. Each turn you battle, any creature that doesn't have summoning sickness attacks the creature across from it, and if there is nothing across from it, it deals damage to the opposing player. At the end of your turn, you discard your entire hand, and draw 5 new cards. After four turns, you level up, meaning you reshuffle all your cards back into your deck, except now some of those cards are higher level. And this repeats, with your deck getting stronger as the game goes on.  There are four factions, and each of them plays differently. Decks are 30 cards, and can be made of one or two factions.From that simple structure, there is a lot of depth in the game. This game was designed by Stoneblade Entertainment, the same company that created the Ascencion deckbuilding game, with the help of Richard Garfield (creator of Magic: The Gathering). Most of them are Magic protour veterans as well. The plan, for now, seems to be to release one major set and one minor update each year. There are timed and untimed matches, as well as tournaments and drafting. The game is built to be free to play, although it is still in beta, so many things like a single-player campaign and trading cards between players are not in yet, but the game is updated fairly regularly. I definitely recommend it to anyone who is keen on strategy games or CCGs, and the free to play nature makes it easy to try out.

Early Access Review
								I love this game. It's strategic, challenging, and surprisingly visually interesting for what's essentially a cardgame. It definitely rewards long-term play and/or monetary investment, but it isn't PTW  and you scale quickly without any investment. I also like how it would be impossible to play in the real world - that is to say, it makes good use of the fact that it's on a computer, rather than mimicing already extant cardgames like M:TG. I would (and do!) recommend this one to friends.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 29, 2014
Early Access Review
								This is a fun game to play, and it's easy to pick up the rules and jump right in.  For a casual gamer like myself, that is a big plus.  The mechanics of "leveling" a card were new to me at first and took a little bit of time to get the hang of, but the best times I've had are figuring out good combos to play.  I played M:tG years and years ago, and at first I tried to approach SolForge like that, but I was not very successful.  I like that there are a bunch of powerful cards that you can work towards and hope that they turn up in a booster, but the ability to purchase basic booster packs using silver you win in game is a much easier way to start growing your collection.  I don't like that you can't trade cards (hopefully that get implemented in some fashion, someday down the road), and all the tournaments that I have entered were filled with very powerful decks (so I lost almost every time), but overall, this game is a great way to spend 15-30 minutes at a  time.  It's still in beta right now, and they tweak the cards when trying new game balances, but it is very polished and I have only had one or two instances where something buggy happened.  Lag is sometimes an issue too, but that might be my local connection more so than anything in the game itself.  Give SolForge a try, it is worth it.

								SolForge is a strange and quite unique CCG. It contains four "Factions" modeled after Technology, Nature, Life and Death. Each Faction does have it's advantages and disadvantages and you must combine two factions together to create a near-perfect card-dispensing, death-dealing deck! However SolForge is not quite as polished as other CCG's like Magic the Gathering or Hearthstone, nor is it as publicized. However It is worth playing equally as much as the other CCGs. Originality: 6Mechanics: 7Polish: 5Rating: 6/10 SolForge is an interesting game, though it lacks the polish others of it's genre have.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: March 17, 2015
Early Access Review
								The game is playable and reasonably entertaining from a basic playability standpoint; but deck building is an exercise in needless frustration and there are massive issues with competitive online play that doom SolForge to meet an early grave. I won't waste time describing the same issues others already have: Timed and untimed matches encourage abuse. Trolls either wait until the clock is about to run out before they play, or they leave untimed matches sitting there until the opponent concedes to get rid of it. A single mediocre draw basically ends your game because there's no way to catch up once you're behind The interface has obnoxious inconsistencies (i.e. Double-click does very different things in differet screens) Very laggy performance, especially in the deck builder Many other issues...Instead, I'm going to focus on a single point that has grown to end any chance of the game being playable for any incoming player. At this stage, there's no realistic way to compete with players that have been around for months because their decks are loaded with the rarist cards in the game (legendary and heroic). Catching up at this stage would require an investment of several hundred, or even thousands of dollars.I've played dozens of people, to the point that I see certain names often enough that I know their decks and what to expect; and every card in their deck is wildly more powerful than almost every card I've been able to get in more than a month of play. At this point, I'm pretty sure the only people still active in the game are long-term players. The few new players come in briefly, see how much of a mess it is, and promptly leave.It's a complete waste of time to invest in this game, even if the balance issues are worked out, the cheating/trolling is curtailed, and more players join. Save yourself the hassle and find something else to do with your time.

content:
Posted: March 13, 2015
Early Access Review
								I'm an avid Magic: the Gathering player and all-around CCG player. With that said, I think SolForge is one of the best and quickest paced card games I've played in the 18+ years I've been playing card games. I would definitely recommend this game to any and all CCG fans that I know. The best thing about the game truly has to be the leveling and ranking. This is something that I haven't seen in any other CCG before and greatly enjoy.The worst part about this game is that after most all update (especially when new sets come out) there is always a long list of bugs that come with. Most players will experience anything from not being able to create/update decks all the way to failing to load the game at all.Overall this is a great game that I think most players familiar to CCG's would love and could easily devoted many hours to like I have.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: June 9, 2014
Early Access Review
								It's sad but I got sick of that game.SolForge brought amazing new ideas to the cards game universe. You have a deck of 30 cards. Each turn, you draw 5 cards, play 2 of them and discard the rest. You also put in your discard pile a version of the played card but on the superior level. After 4 turns, you shuffle your discard pile in your deck, unlocking sweet level 2 cards. It goes on until level 3 when you just put an other level 3 card in the discard pile.It might not seem like much but a whole new depth of strategy comes with it. Somes cards are stronger than average on level 3 but terrible on the first level. If you play them, you might lose the hand at the begining of the game but you'll wreck your opponent if you survive. Other are the opposite, you must win fast or you won't have anything good to face his level 3. You might also have to level a specific card to counter something at higher level even if it's not usefull to play at the moment.And, like any card game, there is LOT of different effects on each card, factions to group cards under a same theme and playstyle, card rarity and boosters to buy to improve your collection.But, it is very hard to get a solid grasp on the game. Everything is a little bit more random that in other cards game. Of course, you have to build a good deck to hope drawing the good cards but a good SolForge deck will go haywire a bit more often than in Magic or Hearthstone. (It's still minor because it's part of the game everyone.)It is also very hard to understand the cards alchemy and counters. I mean, most counters are obvious. If your opponent spawn many weak creatures, play a mass spell. But I get myself thinking a lot about why my decks aren't working. Most of them either have a great synergy but doesn't comes that good when it comes to playing. Others are just good cards with minimal synergy that comes good on game but not as good as I could expect.Somes decks seem very strong in the hands of my oponents (even without legendaries) but I can't put them together. It seems like everything turn to ashes when a pick a Tempys deck but I sometimes get wrecked by those in a few turns.And there is the 20 minutes timers issue. (You don't have time for each turns, you have 20 minutes for the whole game. It is too much and easy to abuse.) In my opinion, it is minor but it should have been fixed months ago. (Probably before making new cards.)So, the game is great because you can drop in any moment and begin an untimed game and finish it later but if you really want to enjoy this, you shouldn't get competitive about it. (Not like me.)

content:

Early Access Review
								Compared to Hearthstone and Magic, I really like how this game handles randomness: enough for novel experiences, but you feel much more in control. Got a bad draw? No worries, you get a whole new hand next turn. Legendaries buried in your deck? In just a few turns you'll cycle through the whole thing.The art ranges from meager to gorgeous and the interface can be a little finnicky here and there, but these are definitely forgiveable. The unique mechanics and interesting card effects are worth it.Oh and they give out free cards like craaaazy. Dailies, crafting, and packs are relatively very generous. No need to sink tons of time/money to build a capable and fun collection ::coughcough:: HEARTHSTONE PLS ::cough::

								This game reminds me of Shadow Era, another F2P TCG. The basic concepts are similar; it's just the execution that differs with each game. 								Although not quite as deep tactically as Magic: the Gathering, this is still a very fun card game that elegantly solves some typical CCG issues through its simplicity. number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: September 11, 2014
Early Access Review
								Pros: Wide card selection, easy to learn, and high skill ceiling.Cons: It takes a LOOOOONG time to get anything done. You must double click on a card to view it's card text, but that takes several seconds to pop up and then some more time just to close it. Before you view a card's text, all you see is the art, power, and life. If it showed even a portion of the text box, then I'd be able to tell at a glance if the card is vanilla or not, but I can't. It also doesn't show you the faction (color) of the card without double clicking on it first - which is absurd. This MUST be sped up and changed into a mouse-over if the game is going to proceed at a reasonable speed.Browsing through your card library is very slow. You can either view cards iOS app store style (1 at a time, swiping through hundreds of cards), or in a vertical list (very little information displayed). We need more view options that isn't as extreme as these 2 choices. Viewing card text is a single click, which is different from the main game. Double clicking adds a card to your deck. If you were just trying to read the card text, you'll then have go to a different menu (which is also slow) to remove the unintended card from your deck (and for some reason, the game allows you to add more than max deck size). This could be fixed if you could add cards with a different command, like right click.In game timer is ridiculous. You have 20 minutes total to make all your moves, like speed jenga or speed chess. If that runs out, because either player is playing a defensive deck, then you have to start making moves faster. However, once that time gets down to around the 1 minute mark, you get an additional minute to make your moves, but that minute isn't added onto your total time. So if you had 1:05 left, at the beginning of your turn, you would have 2:05. Then if you finished with 1:10 left, your total time is now 0:10. Then for the rest of the game you have roughly 1 minute to make your moves, which is NOT enough with how SLOW it is to play and read cards. Just put a time limit on individual turns, like 180-200 seconds.The font size in the game log (which is a text version of what moves each player made) is WAY too small. I'm talking like times new roman size 7 on windows. When I tried this on my android device, the text was indistinguishable from the dust and scratches on my screen protector. Probably font size 1.5 there. ALSO! The game log is hidden away in the menu, so it takes even MORE time to access. Since all spells aren't shown to the opponent as they are played (recycled animations are shown instead, so different spells may share the same animation), I have to rely on the game log to see what was played. The log MUST be more accessible and LEGIBLE if the game continues to animate the way it does now. I'm sure there are more problems with the game log, but I couldn't read any of the text. At the very least, I can make out the highlighted text to see the card that was played.Great game with a bunch of potential. Fix these problems and I will gladly return.

								Edited 13/8/2014: It's still an alright game, but I can't honestly reccomend it anymore, I still enjoy playing it every now and then, but there's just too much RNG to make it fully enjoyable for me anymore.OK, as you can probably tell, I have played this game a lot.It's a good game, really easy to wrap your head around the basic mechanics, but has a lot of room for skill growth. If you like card games there's no real point not playing it, as it's Free-to-play. Your card selection will be quite limited to begin with, but if you get your daily rewards regularly you'll start building up a wide variety of cards in no time.While the game can be frustrating at times, when you have unlucky draws and things like that, it's still a game that I have kept coming back to despite these occasional frustrations.There are still features that are needed in the game, mainly card trading and crafting, but these are in development and on the way.I definitely would reccomend this game if you like trading card games, or are interested in starting to play trading card games. As this is one of the most beginner friendly, mechanics-wise, card game that I have played.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: February 26, 2015
Early Access Review
								Pros:Nice big colourful battlefield where you don't have to strain your eyes reading tiny textNo mana dependenceEasy earning of ingame currency with daily logins and 3 winsYou can buy any card with your earned currency (though getting a legendary can take up to 15 days of play)Interesting and complex card interactionsCons:Newbie decks are often matched up with legendary filled decks - this is probably one of the biggest reasons why new players will get discouraged and not stay with Solforge - a newbie would rather wait to be matched up with another newbie than be matched up fast with a super deckYou can only play 2 cards per turn usually, which feels too limiting and drives players inevitably towards the cards which help break that rule - 3 would provide better balance and create even more interesting interactions. Seriously only being able to play 2 cards per turn is a major drag lol. It almost makes me want the mana/resources system back so that I can get to play more than 2 cardsScreen layout and decor still feels a bit stiff and amateurishMost of the strong decks all pack in Nekrium ('black') legendary cards - that is so obvious an imbalance that needs to be addressed and I'm very surprised they haven't yet - are they Satanic programmers or something heheConclusion:If you're a newbie, play it daily for just three wins (can be against computer) until you strengthen your card collection and you won't get frustrated. Remember you can forge any card you want with the silver you earn ingame.The game has great potential, perhaps as much as Magic The Gathering when it first started out, and with new cards introduced regularly and speedily to compete with other card games, especially non-Nekrium legendaries, the game will be more colorful, balanced, varied and interesting. Those are imho the only ways it can genuinely catch up with MTG.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: December 8, 2013
Early Access Review
								Solforge is a free to play digital card game. Now while it may not match up to the likes of Magic, you can still be assured that you'll have some great fun playing this game. As a free to play, Solforge has both its positives and negatives, the latter of course being that it is not an entirely finished game and still has a way to go in terms of mechanics, namely the ability to trade between players and find cards of a particular type. At its heart it's a cheap alternative and it shows, HOWEVER, I would never tell anyone not to play Solforge. The gameplay is simple yet it works fantastically, tying in very well with the game's wide array of cards, each of the four factions bringing clever and interesting options to your decks. The artwork is absolutely gorgeous. With so many great cards and such a simple playstyle, Solforge breaks the card game down to a true battle of wits, while you may have some better cards than the other player, you may not use them well enough to defeat them.NOTE: While I do like this game, online play can some times cause a slow between player turns as it seems unoptimised and there is now way to know who you're playing against (i.e. where they're from). Definitely play Solforge, you won't regret it.

								SolForge is the only online CCG I have seen that makes good use of the online medium: most online CCGs could just as easily be done in cards, and most of them fall short of MtG; leaving me little reason to play them. SolForge, however, uses a leveling mechanism that could not be done in a paper CCG; and exploring the leveling system and the need to think not only what you want to play now; but also what you want leveled for later in the game, makes SolForge the one online CCG I am likely to keep playing.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: October 3, 2014
												I most definetly suggest this game for anyone that is into CCGs.  You may read alot of reviews nagging about the P2W, but what card game isn't.  If you are into MTG, Pokemon, Yugi, or any other CCG then I am sure that you have dropped more money then you would like to think about. Think about it for a momment.  A booster of MTG will cost you $3-$5 depending on the set which will get you 15 cards. Same goes for any CCG. Then there are the single cards that can go for way more than what a booster or even a box will cost you.  If you are a serious CCG player then you know what I am talking about. I didn't start paying for things until I had played for a few months.  I figured that the game had provided me with plenty of entertainment that sending a few bucks here and there wasn't a bad idea.  As for this grind people speak about it really isn't that bad.  During your dailies you can get up to 3 free boosters and enough silver to buy 2 more and boosters are worth 5000 silver which will get you 6 cards.  I have also recieved legendary chests as a daily reward as well.  I have collected a majority of my legendaries this way. Yes, I have bought a few of the precon decks, but thats like buying a precon deck with any CCG.   So I do not see the big gripe with the P2W asspect when it is the same for all CCGs.  The other complaint I see a lot is that you need legendaries to win and I call BS on this.  I played for the longest time without legendaries and I would still win online matches against people with stacks of legendaries.  Do legendaries help? Yes, they can. So can mythic rares and rares in MTG but they don't always make the deck. Its all about synergy and knowing how to make a proper deck.  When I played MTG those were my favorite decks to win with.  Playing against people that have dropped hundreds of dollars on their deck where mine would be but a fraction of what they spent.  One of my MTG decks that has yet to lose consists of nothing but commons and uncommons.  I took this tactic over to Solforge and it still works time to time. Like in any game you are going to win some and lose a lot.  You have to keep analysing whats out there and try to think of something that no one else has and surprise people.  If you are into CCG then I say give it a try cause as a person with 18 years of CCG playing I say it is worth it.EDIT:This is gonna be long winded, but there will be a short response below.The comment above was from some time ago and the game has changed a lot since then. I wish the game was still the one my review was originaly for, but it is not. They got rid of the ability to do your dailies against AI and that is the biggest negative thing to me. As you can see I have spent a lot of time (and some money) into this game. I would log in, do my dailies, have some fun with newer cards and then log out. This would take but just a few minutes. Now if I want to get my rewards I have to play online against people that take their sweet♥♥♥♥♥time while I start getting bored and just rage quit you could say. This game was a fun casual CCG and now they are trying to make it very uncasual. Since they have done this the community has dwindled and the game has suffered. Everyone voices what they want, and its all pretty much bring back the way the game was, and they do not listen. That is the other thing; communication with these guys is as slow as a pregnet slug on salt. When they finaly say what changes they have done, no one cares cause it is still in the wrong direction. The forums on their website are nothing but negative responses to what they have done and they dont even reply. All they ever post about are the new cards coming out and once in a full blue moon some sort of update news. I use to look forward to playing this game every day, but now I hardly ever. Truly sad.Pros-Lots of cards to play with-Fun new way to play a CCG with the leveling up of cardsCons-Game is dying-No communication from devs other than to promote new cards-Not new player friendly what so ever. I made an alt account to see if I could do anything and that was a big no go. So unless you have been playing for a while or plan to drop some serious cash, enjoy getting pounded by experienced players and their built decks. Good luck!-No dailies against AI. This was the main way to collect silver, cards, and tournament tokens, but that is gone.-They screwed up the way you could build your decks by limiting the card filters. Before you could easily sort your cards and now its a hassle.-New UI was not needed, I prefer the old beta version (as do many others)Before their "Full Launch" this game was a 10/10 for me. Now its probably a 1/10 sadly. I'll keep logging in everynow and then to see if things have been fixed, but I doubt it will ever be the way it was.

content:
Posted: February 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								After playing SolForge for a while, I can say that it's no Magic: The Gathering, but it isn't bad. You get one booster pack per day just for logging in, you can earn more by winning games, and there's a single-player campaign mode that - while fairly thin - still provides a good tutorial first and a rather crushing bit of challenge later on. Will you run up against truly unfair decks online? Oh, hells yes. Will you eventually make crushingly unfair decks of your own? Sure. All in all, it's not a bad F2P - and I define that as "A F2P that you really don't have to spend money to enjoy."PROS: -Interesting gameplay.-No need to spend money, though earning cards through winning will take time.-Single-player mode intact.-Also available on AndroidCONS: -Some minor balance issues, although some of the most broken cards have been taken care of over time.-Repetitive music.-Getting your first competitive deck together will certainly take a while.Overall: 7/10. One of the better card games available on Steam.

SBE as a fan i have to ask What Went Wrong!!!!!

content:
Posted: January 18, 2014
												Awesome card game, nice detailed art. Matches don't last long because of the leveling system.This leveling system is pretty unique in that it does not in any way reflect a leveling card system outside of the matches. It is in fact you, the player, leveling up and the cards follow suit; which makes the match become faster when someone levels up.Also, as a sidenote. There are three kinds of daily achievements in this stage of the game (early stages). these are 1 the daily login reward, 2 win a match (which is easy when you create match against easy ai) and 3 win three matches. After those rewards, you're capable of buying a couple of small boosters. So at this moment of the game, it's to play 15 min max a day.EDIT  Ok, I've been playing the game for a while longer now and I have to say, my enthousiasm hasn't been depleted. One of the possible login rewards is the event cards which in the end (for example with 3 events cards) permit access to a tournament. The awesome thing is that, when you play that tournament and you lose all three matches, you still receive a normal booster (contains a lot more cards than small booster). If you win one out of three matches, you get your event cards back :o(And I haven't even begon about drafting which, in the end,  gives you even more cards at your disposal (even after tournament).With the adding of Iphone players, the playerbase has become larger which, in turn makes it faster to find an online opponent. AAAAnd if you win your first online match of the day, you receive another reward (this would be the fourth daily achievement). :DLate edit:Do not play game. Expectations are higher than reality.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 16, 2016
Early Access Review
								I have been playing this game for a while now(mostly on phone) and so far it's pretty enjoyable even as a free to play. You can make some decent decks with only common and rare cards and get decent daily rewards. There is one thing that really bothers me and I think most f2p players in this game. There is no ranked system to seperate from normal online matches. Why does this bother me? 9 out of 10 players I face in a normal online match have insane full heroic/legendary decks while I only have some heroics and a few legendaries(which I can not make a decent deck from). I maybe win about 2 out of 5 games I play online but for f2p or new players it is really hard to get started.But besides that it can be pretty satisfying winning a game against players with a full heroic/legendary deck with only common and rare cards. There is a really big cardpool to make and try a lot of different decks and a lot of different and unique card effects.I can't say anything about the tournaments because I never did one of those(might try those later).The UI is pretty bad but it doesn't bother me that much but please Stone Blade, make a ranked system so newer players can get some fair opponents in online mathes.I will give this a 7/10(this could've been an 8/10 if there was a fair matchmaking for online matches). I do recommend trying this out even if it is hard to get started. If you like TCG's with lots of variaty in cards, lots of deckbuilding and tweaking, this can be an interesting game for you.

number of helpful: No ratings yet
content:
Posted: January 2, 2016
Early Access Review
								I've been playing this a lot since the first set was out.This is my go-to game when just chilling with my buddy who also rocks this game.Testing decks, reaching infinity (unlimited plays per turn, nice challenge, try it!)Thinking long and hard about draft choices, debating nerfs. so much fun if you enjoy strategy.Gameplay wise, this is MUCH more interesting than hearthstone, much more choices, less of a reliance on legendary's.One of my strongest decks atm (U/A spawn deck with scarabs, weirwood patr and lifeblood dryad)has only 2 (Ancestral Echoes) but they mostly make the deck slower and worse.Although it really needs a ranking system, I disagree with the p2w sentiment of some other reviews.People seem to think you can only get silver through online matches, but the best way to get cards (and to have major fun on equal footing with other players) is the draft system. The normal draft (3 event tickets, 1(+) ticket per day) nets you 30 cards to keep.this will fill out your collection fast and with the forging of excess cards, this will give you20.000+ gold for each draft. Not to mention the pretty large amount of legendary's i got from winning draft games. Too bad you can grind it all day, but this has given me a full collection everytime before a new set came out.    protip;  NEVER BUY LEGEND CHESTS Just think up a deck which needs them or netdeck the current best or something.Play for 5-10 min every day to get draft tickets > draft > sell > buy specific legendary.this is way better, not all are equal in usefulness and the chances of getting a truly good one are slim.  just get some thundersaurs or nexus aeronauts through buying.To make a long and incoherent story short;Try it, now!  just play it for 10 min of fun every day and soon you will have a decent and viable collection to toy with.tell your friends, we need more ppl playing.And stoneblade, thanks for making this awesome game, but make a ranking system. It is frustrating to go up against  twinked out meta decks if you are new.
